speech.para: He goes on to talk about Simon Crean:

quote.para: And Simon Crean has echoed Brereton's call, telling The Australian Financial Review last week that he has all but ruled out support for a US-led attack on Iraq.

But neither Brereton nor Crean has offered any real analysis of the alternatives to regime change. It's almost as if the British Labour Government's detailed dossiers showing the horrors Hussein has inflicted on Iraqis and the build-up of weapons of mass destruction never existed.

speech.para: I think that is indicative of what various speakers on this side of the parliament have been trying to highlight about the Labor Party and its abject hypocrisy on this issue. Nolan goes on to say:

quote.para: What appears to be beyond the grasp of many of my comrades in the Left is the scale and scope of a modern totalitarian regime such as Hussein's. It is truly—to use Iraqi dissident Kanan Makiya's eloquent term—a republic of fear. It is a police state which conducts its ruthless totalitarian control through more than 100,000 secret police.

speech.para: And so on. Finally, he wants to know `how the leopard could possibly change its spots'. He is of course talking about the Left of the Australian Labor Party. He says:

quote.para: Lest anyone is fooled into believing that ordinary Iraqis strongly support their nation's dictator Hussein, consider the work of Brussels-based International Crisis Group, headed by former Labor foreign minister Gareth Evans. In its informal survey of Iraqi opinion in September and October 2002 in large Iraqi cities, it noted that a significant number of the Iraqis interviewed, with surprising candour, supported the overthrow of Hussein, even if such a change required an American-led attack.

speech.para: In closing, he says:

quote.para: British Prime Minister Tony Blair has articulated such a challenge powerfully and persuasively. It's just a pity his Labor party comrades here have failed to heed his message.

speech.para: That is a pretty eloquent indication of just what some Labor people think about the weak and divisive way in which the Labor Party has reacted to this predeployment of troops.

The government remains hopeful that Iraq will accept the diplomatic demands of the world to end its program of weapons of mass destruction and to destroy the weapons it already has. The best chance of peace is for the United Nations Security Council to resolve to enforce complete compliance with resolution 1441 and for the world community to also insist on Iraq's disarmament. I compliment the Prime Minister on the stand he has taken as the duly elected leader of this country on behalf of the Australian people. I know he has done it in the best interests of Australians and Australia's future security and, like all of my colleagues on this side of the House, I support him. All I can say to the Labor Party is: you ought to be ashamed of the way in which you have disgracefully abused a very serious issue and, more importantly, put a very negative reflection on the men and women who are going to serve this country in whatever conflict or action they have been asked to undertake on behalf of the Australian government and its people.

talk.start.para: —I really think the electors of Hume deserve something better than a representative whose speech on such an important issue constituted reading out newspaper articles from two or three journalists—a very mediocre performance indeed.
—Did he get paid for that?

—Yes, do you still get paid for that? I believe that, when we come to parliament and to public office, we all come to try to do good—to try to do the right thing by ordinary people. But there is no doubt that we are subjected to all kinds of pressures and sometimes end up losing sight of these things and thinking about our own political advantage and interests ahead of those people we are supposed to represent. Frankly, I think that is what has happened in the case of George W. Bush. There are people who say that this is about oil, but one thing I do agree with the Prime Minister about is that this is probably not about oil. If it were about oil, you would imagine that it might have come up years ago or might have been resolved in some other way.

speech.para: What I think is going on here is that he has learned something from the political experience of his father, who was highly successful in the Gulf War in driving Iraq out of Kuwait and whose opinion poll ratings went sky high—above 80 per cent. But he won and, when the war was over, attention in the United States turned to domestic things. Bill Clinton famously said, `It's the economy, stupid,' and went on to beat George Bush Sr. In the wake of September 11, George Bush has gone into Afghanistan—a move which has my full support—and has been successful there, but he has thought to himself, `You know, if this finishes, domestic attention will turn to other things.' I have sadly come to the conclusion that this is all about electoral advantage—that Iraq is not about weapons of mass destruction but is rather, for John Howard and George Bush, a weapon of mass distraction.

Unfortunately, Iraq represents not merely a matter of convenience but also a distraction from the main game. The war on terrorism should be about Osama bin Laden, al-Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiah—not about Iraq, with which there has been no valid connection made. In putting the international focus on Iraq we have taken our eye off the ball, and it is not in Australia's interests for us to focus on Iraq at the expense of these things. Just today, a report from British defence intelligence experts was leaked which said, `There is no current link and the suggestion that there have been any links in the past between Saddam Hussein and al-Qaeda is out of date.' For people who take an interest in these things, Saddam Hussein is not a religious fundamentalist and not an Islamic extremist. He is a pretty common or garden dictator with, as far as I can tell, no genuine religious or other convictions at all. The suggestion is very much that he and al-Qaeda have little in common.

The other issue which has been raised here is weapons of mass destruction. Yes, Saddam Hussein should be disarmed. Yes, we should be vigilant about these things. But the situation of other powers is just as relevant and there is evidence concerning weapons of mass destruction in India, Israel and North Korea as well. Just a year ago, George Bush talked about North Korea as part of the `axis of evil'. Now he says that `quiet diplomacy' is the way to go. The difference is that Iraq is an Islamic nation, and the suspicion amongst people of Islamic background that Iraq can therefore be treated differently is a matter of great concern to those people. I support United Nations processes as the way to deal with this issue. My son Ben pointed out to me a day or two ago, `Dad, people need to remember here what happened with the League of Nations.' When the League of Nations was treated with contempt and that process broke down, it was part of the background to the Second World War. After the defeat of Hitler the powers around the world said, `We've got to do better than this,' and they set up the United Nations. Whatever its sins and shortcomings, it is the way forward. There must be international rule of law.
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

talk.start.para: —Regrettably, the government and the Liberal Party do not support the United Nations. Instead, they prefer to sit on George Bush's lap. We see this not only with the international issue before us, Iraq, but also with things like the Kyoto protocol, where they fail to be part of that collective international action. It is my view that we need to support the United Nations and that unilateral action would be disastrous. I ask those who are prepared to contemplate engaging in unilateral action whether they realise what the consequences of this would be and whether they realise where this would be going. George Bush and, indeed, Tony Blair need to realise what 15-year-old boys in Iraq would think if they believed that there were no rules and that this is just about force, crude might and crude power. In light of this, there would be hundreds of Osama bin Ladens. People need to understand what the consequences of unilateral action would be.

speech.para: International terrorism is indeed a problem. We have got to be tough on terrorism and we have also got to be tough on the causes of terrorism. By all means, we need to hunt down al-Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiah, but we also need to look at things like international aid. We have been too selfish. There are hundreds of millions of people around the world without access to things like decent drinking water and decent sanitation. We also need to put a better international focus on the Middle East. It has obviously been an intractable problem, but we have got to be tougher on Hamas and Arafat on the one side and Sharon and the settlers on the other side.

If the United States and other powers were prepared to apply the international blowtorch to the Middle East in the way that they are prepared to apply it to Iraq now, then maybe we would get something in relation to the settlements and the occupied territories. And maybe we would get something if we were to say to Arafat and the Palestinian Authority, `This dream of one day driving the Israelis into the sea is utter rubbish. It is never going to happen and you need to have the guts to tell your people that.' Government members have outlined a catalogue of evils on the part of Iraq, sure; but we do not go in and take out every evil regime. We talk about Zimbabwe. We need to learn some of the lessons of Vietnam, where regimes imposed by force from outside are unlikely to get popular support and are unlikely to succeed.

In conclusion, the Howard government's forward deployment is absolutely wrong. It represents clear support for the inevitability of war when we should be doing everything we possibly can to avoid war. We have once again become a US lap-dog. This Prime Minister is the most sycophantic towards the United States of any Prime Minister since Harold Holt with his infamous `all the way with LBJ' performance. It has been a matter of seeking political advantage—regrettably by scaring people. I remember when the Prime Minister came to power and he talked about making people `relaxed and comfortable'. Instead, we are being turned into `alert but not alarmed'; indeed, a `fearful and scared' community. I appeal to the Prime Minister to think about what kind of country we have become and are becoming; I ask him to think about what kind of world we have become and are becoming. We can do much better than this.
Debate (on motion by Dr Stone) adjourned.

motion.para: That Iraq—Ministerial statement—Motion to take note of paper: Resumption of debate be referred to the Main Committee for further debate.

debate.para: The SPEAKER (5.35 p.m.)—I advise the House that the Deputy Speaker has fixed Monday, 10 February 2003, at 4.30 p.m., as the time for the next meeting of the Main Committee, unless an alternative day or hour is fixed.
Dr STONE (Murray—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage) (5.35 p.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —With all the world's attention focused on Iraq's weapons of mass destruction and a possible war with Iraq, it would seem that North Korea has been left to advance its own nuclear program undeterred. Ever since George Bush's `axis of evil' speech, North Korea's attitude to the West has chilled. Now it seems this sleeping giant is stirring once again—or at least letting us know that it was only snoozing for a while.

speech.para: In the past few months, North Korea has reignited its nuclear program. It has confessed that it was enriching uranium and that it has restarted plutonium reactors—effectively tearing up global nuclear treaties—and it has also announced plans to resume ballistic missile testing. On top of this, it has recently been confirmed that North Korea possesses up to three nuclear warheads already, with several more on the way. Foreign Minister Alexander Downer seems to think that North Korea's actions do not amount to a regional threat, let alone a global threat. The Federation of American Scientists lists North Korea as having—or having the ability to acquire—nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, apart from the ones that it already possesses. This is a full arsenal, and it also has a full ability to deliver them.

While the federal government commits 2,000 troops to the Gulf in anticipation of a war in Iraq, it sends but three public servants to North Korea to deal with a potentially catastrophic nuclear proliferation crisis. By attempting to disarm one nation, it is ignoring serious efforts to re-arm in another. The US Deputy Secretary of State, Richard Armitage, claims that the major difference between Iraq and North Korea is that North Korea wants nuclear technology for economic gain but not terror. I gain very little if no comfort at all from that assumption. I still believe in the adage that countries that possess weapons of mass destruction have a `use it or lose it' mentality.

Iraq does not have the ability to strike at our region, let alone Australia, with a weapon of mass destruction. However, this should not deter us from disarming Saddam Hussein. North Korea on the other hand does have such weapons. They possess a missile called Taepodong-2, which can carry a nuclear warhead all the way to our backyard and into Australia. By ignoring the security of our own region, the federal government is letting a crisis there balloon out of control. What is happening in North Korea has the potential to impact upon Australia far more than a war with Iraq would, especially as we know there is the potential for nuclear and ballistic weapons to be involved.

How can John Howard, the Prime Minister, say that he is acting in the best interests of Australia if he does not stand up on this issue? This government obviously has the wrong priorities and no idea of how to manage our most important policy area—regional security. Australia is one of the few countries left in the world that still has diplomatic relations with North Korea, and we should be making the most of that relationship to address this crisis. The Minister for Foreign Affairs should be on the plane to Pyongyang—and, if Mr Downer has no success, the situation is grave enough to warrant the Prime Minister making the trip himself. Even if this potential threat is really only a form of fantastic bluff to get more foreign aid out of the West, the real prospect that this strategy may work threatens our strategic role in the region and amounts to an upping of the ante on how to deal with nuclear powers, particularly those such as North Korea.

Labor leader Simon Crean committed Labor to re-establishing the Canberra Commission on the Elimination of Nuclear Weapons. This should be commended and supported. Mr Crean also said that what is happening in North Korea represents a serious deterioration of Australia's regional security interests and, as such, Australia cannot sit by and let this important issue be handled by others. Nuclear weapons are the ultimate weapon of mass destruction. They are perhaps the most serious threat to our global community, and we must make a stand. In this struggle to disarm Iraq and rid the world of weapons of mass destruction, we have underestimated North Korea's role. North Korea's part in this crisis is paramount, and downplaying their actions is a gross miscalculation. It shows once again this government's total disregard for and miscalculation of the threats in our region.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of my constituents, I would like to take this opportunity to express our great sadness at the tragic accident at Waterfall last week. A number of families and individuals from my electorate were travelling to Wollongong on this train. I have spoken to a number of these people and my sympathy—and I am sure the sympathy of the members on both sides of this House—goes out to them.

speech.para: One of my constituents, Andrew Ludmon, who lived in Cronulla, was killed on the train. This was particularly tragic and my sympathy goes out to his family. I would also like to express my thanks, on behalf of the community and my electorate, to the ambulance officers, the nurses, the doctors and the emergency crews who were all involved in making the rescue a first-class effort. In fact, I notice in the review of how it was handled that it was regarded as a copybook exercise in terms of the way all the emergency crews worked together in carrying out the strategic plan for what happens in a major accident.

Having been involved myself with a very tragic accident in Brooklyn during my days in New South Wales politics, I know how difficult this can be for those at the scene. Certainly, the crew carried out their duties in a first-class manner. I spoke to one of the ambulance officers involved; they basically worked around the clock and did a magnificent job. Everyone was exhausted by the time the job ended, but it was carried out excellently.

A particularly tough time has been had in my electorate recently in terms of people being killed accidentally. In Bali we lost four young people. I attended the funerals of several of those people. One of those funerals took place following the rising of the House; it was for a person who later died of burns received in that accident. She struggled for about 50 days and clung on to life but was so badly burnt—she had burns to 75 per cent of her body—that it was just too much. The unfortunate thing is that her sister was also killed in the accident, and so the mother was just devastated. Two beautiful young women in the prime of life had their lives snatched away by the terrorists—whom we are now dealing with—in the bombing in Bali. So, although we talk in generalities, these are the specifics. The many hundreds of people who turned up to that funeral were all deeply touched by the event.

In terms of the rail crash, one member of my electorate was on the train, a guy called Gareth Redshaw, who featured on the front page of the Sunday Telegraph. He claimed to me that he dialled Triple 0 on four separate occasions, but it was not until the fourth dialling that it was recognised that he was making a genuine call. He could not get reception first off so he climbed to the top of the cutting, and he said that they did not recognise his call.

I was so concerned about this that I rang the minister at home, and he said he would launch an immediate investigation. The tapes were reviewed. It would appear that the message was passed through to the ambulance service and it is claimed that they did put action in place. Obviously, the young man was very upset at the time, but we are continuing to work on the matter. He was travelling in the third carriage of the train and he was lucky to survive. The family, of course, are quite devastated by the accident but particularly by the problems that occurred.

In conclusion, I will say that, although it is very easy to point the finger, I would like to have an explanation from Mr Scully as to why the black boxes were not fitted. A black box would have provided an excellent record of what went wrong in this accident. I think we can look at the reasons why they were not installed and also ensure that they are all installed in the near future. Then, if there are any future accidents—and we hope that will not happen—we will have a complete record of the reasons why these very tragic accidents occur. Thank you for the opportunity to speak on this matter.

talk.start.para: —I take the opportunity this afternoon to speak further to the motion moved in the House on Tuesday by the Prime Minister regarding the recent bushfire emergency in Canberra and bushfires in Australia generally, sadly. I thank the House for the opportunity to address that particular motion. Today I want to make some additional comments, which time did not permit me to do on Wednesday when I spoke in the Main Committee. Before I go on to those comments, I take this opportunity to thank those members of the House who offered their sympathy and thoughts to the community of Canberra, and my electorate specifically, during the debate on the motion. I can assure those who made those comments that their words and thoughts have been very well received by me on behalf of the community and I will be passing them on.

speech.para: As I said during the debate on this motion, the extent of the damage is now becoming far more clearly identified. The work of the ACT authorities continues. An example of that is the emergency centre that has been set up in part of the Lyons Primary School. The Lyons Primary School is operating well for the new school year, but there are some unused buildings to its rear in Launceston Street in Lyons which have been converted into the Lyons emergency centre and they are operating extremely well. They began to be used for that purpose on the Friday after the bushfires. On the Saturday morning I happened to be there as JP on a voluntary roster of JPs and the place looked like it had been there for six months, not two days. The ACT Public Service and everybody involved have to be commended for their efforts with the services that they are operating. Basically, it is a one-stop shop for every conceivable inquiry. Federal authorities, such as Centrelink, and also New South Wales government authorities have set up shop there and are doing extremely good work. That centre will, I understand, be remaining there for some months.

The real tasks ahead of us now in this community are support, recovery and rebuilding. The involvement and support of the building sector—through the MBA and other organisations—the business sector right across the ACT and region, the ACT authorities and the public sector generally are vital to that process. And they are all to be commended on their efforts to date. The Chief Minister of the ACT has set up a recovery task force. Attached to that is a community and expert reference committee comprising 16 people, some of whom have lost their homes. To participate in that process in those circumstances is, to me, just a little unbelievable, but they are doing a wonderful job. I am happy to have been invited to go onto that group, and it is going to be a pleasure to work with those people on that reference committee.

The people who lost their homes are now going through a terrible decision process: do they stay and rebuild or do they move on elsewhere? It seems to me, from what I am hearing from my community, that the overwhelming majority will be staying. Some have already made up their minds very clearly; some are still going through that process; and others are still maybe a little hesitant. But it is fair to say that the majority appear to wish to stay. They want to do that because they have for some time been in suburbs and surroundings and communities that they know and that they want to continue to live in. Some may decide otherwise. I am aware of one family—a tragic story—who lost their home to a house fire not many years ago, rebuilt and then lost it again during this bushfire. Maybe they will have a different opinion. I am sure our hearts go out to people like that who have been hit so hard.

During this whole process we must ensure that these families are protected from any questionable practice on the part of real estate agents, builders or any other agencies or operators with whom they have contact. We are already aware of some overzealous real estate operators—they are in the minority—who see themselves as facing a bit of an opportunity. They are being warned off by government, by the community and by their peers in the real estate industry. I am hoping that they may convert and display the sensitivity that is required. I know that the agencies within the real estate industry here will do all they can to support our community during this time.

There is one more thing I want to quickly comment on, and that is the emotional aspect of this. These people are facing financial, family and emotional stress that some of us would find hard to understand. Agencies like Lifeline, Kidsline, the Salvos, St Vinnies and Centrecare are all doing wonderful work in supporting them. The most important thing to remember is that no-one should be afraid of seeking help. I remember hearing on the radio a woman who had lost her house to a bushfire 20 years ago, and she said, `I wish I had sought counselling then; my life might have been different.' So I encourage anybody who thinks they should have counselling to get that help as soon as they can.

talk.start.para: —A very exciting opening happened on the Gold Coast earlier this week. Graeme and Wendy Gardiner officially opened a state-of-the-art chess centre. It is the first of its kind in Australia, and I am proud to say that the centre is located in Mudgeeraba in the electorate of McPherson. This opening is the culmination of 12 years of commitment and dedication by Graeme. It has been his dream for many years to purpose build a chess centre to meet the growing demand on the Gold Coast and, indeed, nationally for a centre such as this.

speech.para: Graeme Gardiner is a founding member of the Gold Coast Chess Club, which came into being in 1991. Graeme has spent many hours since the formation of the club endeavouring to establish chess in Australia, particularly for junior school children. He started the Gold Coast primary and high school teams chess championships in 1991 with 40 participants, which grew to more than 1,000 primary students from 250 schools across Australia participating in 2002. It was an Australian record. The Prime Minister briefly visited the 2001 Gold Coast primary schools chess championships during his visit to the Gold Coast and he could not believe that close to 700 primary school students were sitting down to contest the championships. It has been a remarkable and wonderful success story for Graeme and all those young students who have taken up the sport of chess.

Over the years, Graeme has encouraged Gold Coast schools to take up the sport and employ professional coaches for the students. Graeme estimates that 50 per cent of schools in the Gold Coast region now have some type of organised chess program—all due to Graeme's commitment and love of the game of chess. Mr Gardiner has written a comprehensive chess-coaching course, currently being taught on a co-curricular basis at Somerset College, All Saints Anglican School and St Stephens College. The course is also available to schools throughout Australia.

The new chess centre at Mudgeeraba includes a tournament room with state-of-the-art computer equipment, a cafe offering gourmet delights as well as Internet access and a shop stocking chess sets and other related items. The chess centre will cater for all levels of chess players, from beginner to grandmaster, and is open from 3 p.m. to 10 p.m. Monday to Friday. Mr Gardiner aims to expand the number of children involved in playing chess and also to target adults and get them more involved. The chess centre will provide a wonderful environment for players to not only enjoy the game of chess but also aspire to be champions. But the game of chess is not just played for social benefits; it has proven educational benefits. The game has improved cognitive development and helped develop critical and creative thinking, reasoning and memory. Significant improvements in mathematics results and reading scores have been documented, and chess also helps with problem solving skills.

The journey to this wonderful opening of the chess centre has not been without some pain and certainly a lot of frustration for Graeme Gardiner. For many years now Graeme has been trying unsuccessfully to have the game of chess recognised in this country as a sport—and therein lies the problem. The playing of chess is not a sport, nor is it recognised as education. Many other countries around the world recognise and fund chess as a sport. Why not Australia? Chess in this country receives no funding from any level of government. Yet last year the department of immigration determined that an Indian grandmaster of chess was indeed a professional sportsman and charged him double for his visa. We have the ridiculous situation where one government department decides that chess is a sport and another—the Australian Sports Commission—deems chess not to be a sport. This situation is sending mixed messages from our government and is not helping to build the sport of chess.

We lost to America a young lady who was just 13 years old and a recognised international champion. With a lack of any funding by the federal government, this young lady and her family migrated to America where she was offered a $77,000 per annum chess scholarship at the University of Texas. This young lady could have been ours. Time tonight does not allow me to explore the vexed question of whether we should recognise chess as a sport. However, I believe this issue should be addressed. Imagine if Australia hosted a chess Olympiad with around 2,000 to 3,000 people from around the world descending on our country. What sort of export dollars would that earn for our country? I congratulate Graeme and his wife, Wendy, for chasing the dream and seeing it come to fruition. But I put my government on notice that I will not give up trying in the future to have chess recognised as a sport.

talk.start.para: —Many members would be aware of the serious decline in the number of doctors who provide bulk-billed medical services in the electorates. Since the Howard government was elected in 1996, it has become harder and harder to see a doctor who is prepared to bulk-bill, making visits to the doctor much more expensive for Australian families. In my electorate of Charlton, only 66.8 per cent of GP services are now bulk-billed—that is down from 78.6 per cent two years ago. Many of the bulk-billed consultations are provided to pensioners and healthcare card holders. Thus, the percentage of working families who receive bulk-billed services would be well below 50 per cent. This is hurting the families that I represent and it is just not good enough. How can this be justified?

speech.para: Across Australia, more than three million fewer services a year are being bulk-billed than in 1996 when the Howard government was first elected. These figures are particularly disturbing as those who can least afford to pay are also those at greatest risk of chronic illness or disease. This cannot be good for the long-term health of Australians. It is of great concern that many age pensioners and other low-income earners are disadvantaged when doctors are forced to demand payment in full, up-front and the patient then is required to claim the refund from a Medicare office. Those patients do not have the same access to health care that other members of the community have, and the universality of Medicare is being compromised by a lack of bulk-billing services.

The federal government provides little incentive for general practitioners to bulk-bill. This deepens the divide between those who can afford health care and those who cannot. Labor maintains that bulk-billing services should be available to all Australians, irrespective of income. Medicare is a universal health care system. The Howard government has put in place measures to gradually eliminate Medicare's universal character. These measures are making access to health care more difficult for ordinary families and those less well-off in our community. Do not forget that this Prime Minister said he wanted to take a knife to Medicare—and this is possibly death by a thousand cuts. Private health insurance is an optional extra and no-one should feel pressured into purchasing it. Medicare should cover all Australians. Since coming to office the Howard government has undermined Medicare by cutting rebates, driving down bulk-billing and closing Medicare offices. Medicare rebates for medical procedures have not kept up with the increasing costs faced by doctors. These measures have all contributed to the decline in bulk-billing. The government has a responsibility to increase the Medicare rebate for doctors' services and should provide incentives to encourage general practitioners to bulk-bill.

I have been approached by many constituents who simply cannot find doctors who will provide a bulk-billing service. There was even an instance when a quite distraught woman approached me because she had found suspicious lumps in a breast and simply could not find a doctor who would bulk-bill and she did not have enough money to pay a doctor up-front. It is this sort of thing that the Liberals have no concept of. This government does not understand that many of my constituents live by a very strict and tight budget and, if you get sick, there is no money to see the doctor. People rely on bulk-billing. When people's health is being threatened because they cannot afford to see a doctor or because doctors' books are full, the government must act to ensure access to health care services for all.

The Medicare rebate for general practice consultations has not risen in line with inflation for many years. The costs associated with running a practice have increased at a faster rate than the growth of the rebate. With the introduction of the Howard government's GST, doctors' costs have risen extraordinarily. Doctors need to cover their costs, which means rising prices for patients. In order to ensure equity of access to free health care, the government must work with doctors to come up with a plan that will encourage doctors to bulk-bill. Many people are concerned about the pressure being placed on our public hospitals. The simple fact is that, when people need to see a doctor but cannot because the doctor's books are closed or because they do not have enough money, the only alternative is to turn up to a hospital to seek help. The Howard government is shifting health care costs onto the state government. Despite the NSW Carr Labor government increasing health funding, pressure continues to be placed on our hospitals by the federal government. Bulk-billing and the integrity of Medicare must be preserved. My constituents in Morisset, Toronto, Cardiff, Elermore Vale, Wallsend and all the other towns are entitled to bulk-billing, and this government should ensure its provision.
Question agreed to.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talker.name: Bailey, Fran, MP
FRAN BAILEY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I want to place on record my appreciation and thanks to the thousands of volunteer firefighters who have performed so superbly in recent bushfires. I also want to place on record my appreciation of the Australian Defence Force involvement in the bushfires. Australian Defence Force personnel again demonstrated strength of character and versatility as they worked shoulder to shoulder with on-the-ground firefighters over the holidays against some of the most fearsome bushfires we have seen in this country. Faced with an enemy of a different kind, defence personnel were quick to respond to the call from emergency service workers to strengthen the lines of defence against raging firestorms in north-east Victoria, Canberra and New South Wales.

speech.para: In the great spirit of the Anzacs, hundreds of personnel postponed regular duties to lend a mate a hand, providing invaluable backup and support personnel to weary firefighters who in some cases had been working at clearing firebreaks for several weeks. As well as supplying much-needed manpower, Australian Defence Force support included the provision of: bulldozers, water tankers, fuel tankers, buses and drivers, heavy vehicles and utilities, generators, accommodation, bedding and rations, graders, chainsaw operators and a fire truck, as well as defence planners and transport and logistics operations staff. The ADF also provided six helicopters: two fitted with water buckets, two for fire spotting and two for transporting firefighters. Also, 100 Army personnel were deployed in north-east Victoria to help contain bushfires in the rugged high country, hand clearing massive firebreaks around communities already suffering and counting the cost of peak tourism season minus the tourists.

As we have come to expect, defence personnel acted with the utmost professionalism, stamina and courage to support the efforts of the volunteer firefighters and emergency service workers, pitching in to defend our rural communities against the peril of the firestorms. It has become an all too familiar sight—those men and women, who pledge to protect the security of our nation and uphold our global obligations, taking up tools of another sort to protect and care for so many of our communities: in cams, fighting fires alongside the CFA; or combining air and sea rescue; or, as they did just recently, using heavy vehicles to clear a path through bush to enable paramedics to access accident scenes. We have seen those vivid pictures, and I want to place on record my thanks and say what a great privilege it is to have those wonderful men and women of our Australian Defence Force there to come to the rescue.

talk.start.para: —As the House will know, Australia is in the grip of a bushfire crisis. In my home state of Victoria, as in other parts of the country, the fires have been particularly fearsome and extensive. It was with some concern that I rose this morning to news that fires had broken out in the Otway Ranges and could threaten many townships in that area. Although this area is in the seat of Corangamite, which is represented by Mr Stewart McArthur, it is an area I know very well having grown up in the western district of Victoria. Today in the brief time available to me I would like to pay particular tribute to firefighters from Geelong and the surrounding region, who to date have made an enormous contribution to fighting fires in not only Victoria but also other states of the Commonwealth. I echo the sentiments that have been expressed here this morning by the member for McEwen.

speech.para: We in Geelong have a deep respect for that contribution because we experienced tragedy first-hand when we lost a crew of volunteer firefighters in the Linton fire in 1998. Five of our finest perished in that blaze. I note that this week we mourn the tragedy in the United States when astronauts died during the re-entry of the space shuttle. In 1998, in a fire tanker in Linton, Victoria, five of Geelong's finest perished, so we understand the sense of tragedy that nations feel in these sorts of circumstances. I am informed that well over 400 firefighters from the region have participated in firefighting activities in Victoria and interstate. That is a magnificent effort. One can only imagine the trepidation of the families of our local firefighters as their loved ones head out to do their job—a trepidation born out of our own harsh experience.

On behalf of the Geelong community, I thank those firefighters and their families for their efforts and contributions to the state of Victoria and to the nation. I give particular thanks to the employers of the volunteer firefighters in the Geelong community. Many of these employers have small businesses, but they quite willingly allow their employees to participate in these community activities. In many respects, they too are the unsung heroes of this battle that we have been waging over the summer in protecting our communities from the ravages of fire.

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Penrith region is one in which families are increasingly choosing to live. Thirty-two per cent of dwellings in this area are fully owned and, more importantly, 35 per cent are in the process of being purchased. The ABS is yet to release further statistics, but it is a fairly safe bet to say that the majority of people purchasing these dwellings are young families. Thirty-nine per cent of the people in the electorate are married, and 23 per cent are children under the age of 15. Put simply, Penrith is a place where people like to bring up their children.

speech.para: Too many people in this electorate travel for four hours to and from work each day. Some say goodbye to their children before 6 a.m. as they hurry off to the train station and do not see them again until after 7 p.m. Others drive to work, to either the city or Parramatta—some even drive to Chatswood or Wollongong. Each day they pay money to use a road that, for much of the morning, is a car park. Such a lifestyle places an intolerable burden on the families that live in my electorate. The quality of life of so many families in this area would be improved if both mothers and fathers could work close to home.

In Sydney's outer metropolitan ring alone, the state government plans to build 31,330 dwellings. My concern is that Carr's efforts at urban planning will fill suburbs like Penrith with these houses without the provision of infrastructure such as roads, hospitals and schools. If you think the M4 is bad now, just wait five years. The Property Council of Australia has warned the state government that it has focused on residential housing at the expense of employment land. Carr's government has ignored necessary economic accessories and infrastructure and jobs to support an ever growing population. The Penrith CBD needs to employ 20,000 people by 2011 just to maintain 25 per cent employment in the local area. The other 75 per cent commute on an obsolete, overcrowded train system or use a chronically congested M4.

This brings me to the North Penrith army land site. The Department of Defence owns a considerable amount of surplus defence land in this area. The land is surplus to requirements, and the Commonwealth has undertaken to sell the land. That is where the Commonwealth involvement ends. The planning and the nature of the development on that site is the responsibility of the state government and the Penrith City Council. The Penrith City Council has drawn up plans for the development of the site. The plan is based around several key planning principles. The first is to promote development in accordance with the state government's metropolitan strategy initiatives for high-density dwellings adjacent to town centres and transport infrastructure. This means mass townhouses and flats next to a railway line. The plan is to place a large amount of housing right in the heart of the Penrith CBD. People already avoid driving down High Street due to congestion. Parking is limited, as commuters desperate for a parking space at 7 a.m. have taken all the available parking. Penrith train station is already congested, as there are many people at peak hour waiting more than 50 minutes to pick someone up from a late train.

The plan has no long-term vision for Penrith. It ignores the Property Council of Australia's recommendation to place an emphasis on employment zones. The result of this plan will be to turn Penrith into a dormitory suburb for the city. Furthermore, it lacks a coordinated provision of infrastructure, like schools and hospitals. Planning such as this will see Sydney turn into a sea of houses from the Blue Mountains to the ocean, with employment centred around the city, North Sydney and Parramatta. I am pursuing an alternative plan for the development of North Penrith army land, which places an emphasis on parking and commercial and high-tech industrial sites, similar to Norwest Business Park. The goal here is to provide quality employment in the Penrith region so families can live and work in the same area. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to put on the record my opposition to the location of one nuclear waste dump for Australia in Woomera, South Australia. The plans and intention to do so by the federal government through its Minister for Science are reckless, foolhardy and short-sighted. That the 14 federal South Australian politicians from the government have been rendered silent on this issue is illuminating indeed and shamefully so. That a final decision could rest with the environment minister is like putting a fox in charge of the chicken coop.

speech.para: It is a given that responsibility for the consolidated location of low-level nuclear waste should be the federal government's. It is also a given that, whatever decisions are made, controversy will prevail. But that does not mean that commonsense and responsible policy are not possible. Responsible decision making will locate low-level nuclear waste in each of the states that create the waste and benefit from the material. The current dump site at Woomera known as 52A is not only unsuitable but also unsafe and potentially dangerous. Site 52A is located next to a missile, rocket and weapons testing range in the Commonwealth controlled Woomera prohibited area. It is a bit like building houses next to pine forests or chemical plants; disaster is certain at some time in the future.

The federal minister assesses the risk as low and within acceptable operational parameters. His assertion is irresponsible and wrong. A direct hit into a nuclear waste facility would be disastrous. Could it happen? Of course it could. Last year a burning Japanese booster rocket crashed just a few kilometres from the site.

My constituents in Port Adelaide who have spoken to me on this matter have a consensus view. The location of any nuclear waste dump next to a missile, rocket and weapons facility is simply unacceptable. Having all risk in one location is not acceptable. Creating the need to transport nuclear waste thousands of kilometres on Australian highways is an accident waiting to happen. Once one site is decided as a low-level site, there is no confidence or trust in this government that it will resist the revenue temptation to create a high-level waste facility as well. My constituents accept that low-level nuclear waste ought to be consolidated in repositories, but without exception they state that the risk should be shared by the states creating the waste and benefiting from the nuclear materials.

We are aware that not only are my constituents in South Australia against the location of the site but significant others are against the location as well. Who are those significant others? They are none other than the Department of Defence and BAE Systems, which runs the commercial operations in Woomera. But the environmental impact statement released in Adelaide last month by the minister made no mention of the concerns of the Department of Defence. What is the minister hiding? Will he come into this chamber and deny those Department of Defence concerns? I bet he does not. I bet the fudge is well and truly on. Where in all of this are the silent Liberal colleagues in South Australia, representing their own state? Where indeed! One site. One state. No way. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On 3 January the Wide Bay town of Gayndah farewelled Claude Alfred Wharton at St Matthew's Anglican Church. The congregation ranged from the humblest citizen to the acting Queensland premier. Claude Wharton, a stalwart of the Bjelke-Petersen parliamentary and ministry teams, died at 88. He held the seat of Burnett from its inception in 1960 to his voluntary retirement in 1986.

speech.para: There was no silver spoon existence for Claude Wharton. He drew a block at Barambah Creek, cleared it himself the hard, backbreaking way, lived on possum and kangaroo stew and rowed his milk cans upstream to his father's property for collection. He was one of that rare breed of determined, hardworking Australians who literally carved out their future from wilderness. Anything he turned his hand to he made a success of: dairyman, citrus and pork producer, grazier, droughtmaster stud cattle breeder, co-op director, peak body councillor and churchwarden.

It was not surprising that the Country Party endorsed him for the new seat of Burnett. He served as Aboriginal and Islander Advancement Minister from 1975 to 1977 but shone as the Queensland Works and Housing Minister for nine years until 1986, in which year he was awarded the CMG. The embodiment of an era where service to community was paramount, Claude Wharton was the perfect grassroots politician. No request, no matter how small, escaped his attention. Courteous and approachable, his door was open in and out of office hours. He always had time for the bloke in the street. Unlike many ex-politicians who slip into benign statesmanship, on his retirement he threw himself back into his Gayndah community as one of the boys—devoted to his lodge and his Rotary Club, and a regular communicant of his Anglican Church.

I salute this friend and mentor, a loving family man and a person of boundless capacity, compassion and commonsense. My sympathies go out to his wife, Pearl; his children, Max, Sheryl and Gary; his six grandchildren; and his sister, Beryl.

talk.start.para: —This morning I want to do something unusual in this three-minute time frame. I want to pay tribute to my mum, Louisa Sarah Quick. I buried her last Friday in Nhill in the Victorian mallee. Mum had a long and distinguished life. She celebrated her 86th birthday last July. Her life was distinguished because she dedicated herself to serving others. This service began over 60 years ago through mum's involvement in the Presbyterian church in Hampton in Melbourne. It was complemented when she met and married dad. As a family, we all moved to Ballarat to care for dad's parents.

speech.para: Dad was a lay preacher in Sebastopol, and he and mum set about establishing a new church in the outer suburbs. Mum's dedication to the young mothers and their children saw this small church blossom and grow to the stage where the church was full to overflowing twice on Sundays and where hundreds of children attended Sunday school. Much to the initial annoyance of us children, mum supported dad's decision to give up his well-paying job as a butcher and take on the role as a lowly paid home missioner for the Presbyterian church. Their first appointment was to be Port Augusta. Port Augusta was followed by Rainbow and Jeparit in Victoria, Glenorchy in Tasmania, East Melbourne, Port Augusta again, and finally Kaniva and Nhill.

In each of these places, as a partner with dad, she immersed herself in the life of the town through the RSL Women's Auxiliary, the CWA, the Red Cross, the mothers' club, the local hospital auxiliary and the Presbyterian Women's Missionary Union, to name but a few. A very 1950s mum, she bottled all sorts of fruit in her Vacola jars. She wasted nothing and could cook great meals on a low budget. She sewed and knitted anything and everything. She could not do without her bank passbook, feared plastic cards and never used an ATM. She was utterly devoted to my late father, Vern. She was devastated when he died in 1984. To her credit, she continued her work in the church in his memory. She loved to replay dad's sermons when she felt down, and just remembering their good times together helped to keep her going so much longer.

Mum was the keeper of the birth dates, phone numbers and up-to-date addresses of all her extended family. She was also a fanatical Melbourne football supporter from her teenage years. Her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren are scattered across the globe. Some reside in the UK, others in the USA and the remainder throughout the states of Australia. Mum spent her final years in the wonderful town of Nhill. I place on record my thanks to the many people there who made mum's life so special. To Dr Anderson and the amazing medical staff at Avonlea and the hospital who nursed her through her last few difficult years, I can never thank you enough for your dedicated and loving care of mum.

Finally, my thanks go to my special mate John Forrest, who took it upon himself to visit and to minister to my mum almost every time he went to Nhill. John saw more of my mum than I did. She really looked forward to catching up with him for a cuppa and a yarn. John took time out from his busy schedule to be with my family at the service and the grave site. Mum has departed this earthly life, but her memory will linger long with us all.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! In accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2002

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 December, on motion by Mr Truss:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Legislation Amendment Bill 2002 introduces reforms to the National Registration Scheme for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals. These reforms are designed to streamline and improve the operation of the scheme created by Labor way back in 1991. Farm chemicals assist Australian farmers, graziers and orchardists to produce quality products for domestic and international markets. Most farmers do, of course, seek to minimise the use of chemicals in their production and they do this for both economic and environmental reasons.

speech.para: It is equally true that the safe use of chemicals makes an important contribution to the productive capacity of our lands—in particular, in Tasmania's beautiful north-west coastal region in my electorate of Braddon, in the south in my colleague Harry Quick's electorate of Franklin and in the north and north-east in my colleague Michelle O'Byrne's electorate of Bass. In addition, these chemicals help Australian primary producers earn valuable export income through commodity and processed food exports. This government's appalling record on trade invests every export dollar earned by our farmers and food processors with even greater value. Australia's most recent trade deficit was the worst in our nation's history—$3 billion worth, the 13th monthly deficit figure in a row and the worst ever. I noticed the Treasurer scurry in to question time yesterday. In between barrages, he got up and tried to defend this worst ever trade deficit in our history in a pathetic way and then he snuck away. Unfortunately, that does not augur well for our economy. It was interesting to see the Treasurer without his normal aggressive aplomb in the House.

As a former college teacher, I have seen some pretty poor report cards, but this report on the government's performance makes all others pale into insignificance. Despite the relatively poor quality of its ministers, this government has been fortunate in many ways. It is fortunate that Labor did the hard work in government to reform and modernise the economy and fortunate that Labor remodelled Australia's relationship with the region and the world and created strong and enduring trade ties in the Asia-Pacific region. It is fortunate also that Labor worked with the states on issues of national significance and introduced national standards such as those that underpin the National Registration Scheme for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals.

On the matter of cooperation, the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry's boast about his `administrative partnership' with the states in his second reading speech is a bit rich. This minister has adopted an antagonistic attitude towards the states—shared, I must say, by many of his other cabinet colleagues. It is an attitude that has hindered rather than assisted national cooperation on matters of national significance. There is no better example of that than the minister's failure to progress reform of the exceptional circumstances program. It is a failure that has cost many farmers on the mainland dearly and one that rural and regional Australia will not quickly forget.

The matter of assessment, registration and regulation of agricultural chemicals is one that Labor primary industries ministers addressed seriously. Under Labor, cooperation with the states was not damaged by the sort of campaign we have seen from this minister in relation to the drought, for example. This minister has been fortunate indeed that Labor's legacy included a functioning, effective national chemical registration scheme. The proper assessment, registration and regulation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals does, of course, provide an important safeguard for the health and safety of Australian consumers and the natural environment. Dependent on this system are no less important matters than the prosperity of Australia's rural industries, the maintenance of our export markets and the health of rural workers, animals and the environment. My electorate of Braddon is home to industries including beef cattle production, poppies, vegetables and food processing. These industries, Minister, benefit immeasurably from the proper use of chemicals and rely on good and sensible regulation to maintain market and commodity confidence in the produce they create.

The National Registration Scheme for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals was, as I mentioned, first agreed between federal Labor and the states in 1991. Between 1992 and 1995 the scheme took shape, with the Commonwealth gaining responsibility for the evaluation and assessment of certain chemical products and their clearance for registration. Since 1995 the National Registration Authority has had responsibility for the evaluation, registration and review of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their control up to the point of retail sale. The states and territories have retained responsibility, on the other hand, for control of use activities.

The bill amends the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code 1994, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992 and the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Products (Collection of Levy) Act 1994. In his second reading speech, the minister told the House the amendments are designed to facilitate a more efficient and effective scheme for registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The minister then outlined the amendments in five very short sentences. The opposition recognises the minister's disdain for detail, but five short sentences is not an adequate explanation for the changes wrought by this bill, Minister. The bill extends—as you know, I hope—to 88 pages and amends three separate acts. The explanatory memorandum tabled by the minister extends to 87 pages. The amendments concern an important national regulatory scheme, and we are told by the minister that the bill reflects an agreement between the Commonwealth and the states and territories. But it is my view that the minister should extend this parliament the courtesy of explaining the detail and impact of the legislation he brings before it. In fact, if we in the opposition had any confidence in the minister, we might well insist he do so before we agree to the passage of the legislation here and in the other place. Regrettably, we lack that confidence.

The key amendments contained in the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Legislation Amendment Bill 2002 include a new low regulatory regime for certain agricultural and veterinary chemicals, which constitutes the response to a recommendation of the national competition policy review of agricultural and veterinary legislation, and expansion of the deemed permits mechanism to ensure stockpiles of chemicals that lose registration can be utilised safely. This utilisation, including disposal, must be consistent with the instructions contained in the deemed permit issued by the National Registration Authority. The amendments also include a new requirement that labels contain instructions for use and that there be greater consistency in the use of language relating to these instructions; an increased capacity for the National Registration Authority to vary conditions of approval, registration and labelling; a new capacity for the National Registration Authority to seek public comment as part of any reconsideration process; increased penalty provisions; and the standardisation of some definitions.

The opposition supports these changes to the National Registration Scheme for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals. In our judgment, the bill will contribute to the efficiency of the scheme by reducing the administrative burden on business. Importantly, the bill will maintain appropriate standards that continue to protect public health, environmental safety and our trade credentials. Labor is pleased, therefore, to lend its support to the passage of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Legislation Amendment Bill 2002.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Braddon for his contribution to the debate. It was a rather interesting contribution, I thought, because usually opposition members complain that ministers' speeches are too long. It was rather different to hear him complain that the speech was too short—although I would have thought that having 87 pages of explanatory memoranda was enough, even for the opposition. But he also chose to make a rather brief contribution, and I welcome the opposition's support for these changes to the legislation.

speech.para: Since 1995, the National Registration Scheme for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals has been established to ensure the safe use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in terms of the health and safety of the community, the environment and our overseas trading relationships. As the regulatory, governmental, community and industry stakeholders have become more confident in the scheme, they have proposed reforms to facilitate a more efficient, effective and responsive regime for the registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. These reforms will hopefully make some contribution to reducing unnecessary red tape, promoting innovation and providing access to safe chemicals for those that need them. The amendments should reduce business and regulatory costs and generally reduce the administrative burden without compromising the health and safety standards we expect from a national registration scheme.

With the implementation of these reforms, Australia's traditionally rigorous and scientifically credible processes and standards will continue to be maintained. All state and territory governments have provided their agreement to this package of reforms. The reforms make good public health and safety sense. They make good sense for the environment and for the small and large businesses that need to access the scheme. I commend the legislation to the Main Committee and thank the opposition for its smooth passage.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 5 February, on motion by Dr Stone:
That the House take note of the paper.

talk.start.para: —Prior to the adjournment of the Main Committee yesterday, I was speaking of the hardships faced by the people of Flinders Island, in my electorate. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport and Regional Services will soon be conducting hearings on Flinders Island to receive submissions about the problems that restrict transport services, at present on a daily basis. The people of Flinders Island, like everyone in Australia, are entitled to protection from the threat of bushfires. Tasmanian life was given a severe jolt by the fires of 1967. On that occasion more than 110 origins were identified in the main fire area, which was just within a 56-kilometre radius of Hobart. Ninety of these fires had started prior to 7 February, and all but 20 were freely burning that morning. It appears that little suppressive activity had been attempted.

speech.para: Seasonal conditions had not helped. September and October rainfall had been well above average and pasture and undergrowth prevailed as a result. But the following months were drier than normal and, by 6 February, grasslands in the southern half of the state were in their most inflammable state. Combined with their density after the spring rains, that was the cocktail mix for the disaster that followed. But it was not simply nature that contributed. Eighty per cent of the fires were found to have been deliberately lit—many for grazing purposes, to bring on new growth before winter; others for malicious reasons. The really sad thing was that many of those who lit the fires had definite land management objectives in mind and did so in reasonably good faith, according to Macarthur's report, with little or no thought that the fires so lit could cause damage and even loss of life.

It is fair to say that we have come a long way in terms of fire risk management and prevention strategies since then. But more is needed. Australia needs a national bushfire strategy. History has shown—and I think it has been dramatically demonstrated by Canberra's experience in 2003—that there is no one area of this country that feels the annual brunt of fire. It is a natural disaster that affects almost every corner of the country over time but, of course, without a timetable. It makes sense to have a national approach to fighting fires so that our combined resources can be directed efficiently and effectively to where they are most needed. Of course, we do that now—the cross-jurisdictional commitment to fighting fires or to supporting any other disaster relief effort goes on without question—but no single state or territory, or even the federal government, can provide the expenditure for sufficient resources to cover every eventuality within its own jurisdiction. I urge all parties in every Australian parliament to work towards a truly national bushfire strategy for this country. Now is not the appropriate time for finger pointing—and those who have done so have caused great pain in our community—but there is no better time to start on a considered program of bushfire safety review.

talk.start.para: —I will only speak for a short while on this issue. I want to place on record my concern about the bushfires and, in particular, the tragic events that happened in Canberra. I think most people know that I spent my early formative days in Canberra. My first two children were born in Canberra, before I moved to Queensland. In 1997-98, I served as Minister for Regional Development, Territories and Local Government and had ministerial responsibility for Canberra, so I have a special affinity with Canberra, its people and the life that they live here.

speech.para: The member for Bass mentioned natural disasters; Australia is indeed the great `wide, brown land'. We have a great range and variety of conditions here. In 1974 I was at home on Christmas Day when I was called in to the natural disaster headquarters as Cyclone Tracy hit Darwin. I thought that I would hold the fort there for about two or three hours, but I finished up going home three days later. That gives an indication of the types of disasters that hit different places in this country. Then, when I was minister for territories, we had the Katherine floods, which were a one-in-a-hundred-years event.

On 13 January a young chap called Duncan Patrick, who is a helicopter pilot—his parents come from Noosa in my electorate—had a tragic crash in a helicopter up in the Brindabellas, outside of Canberra, while fighting the bushfires. I think the whole nation read about the gallant and brave way that Jon Stanhope, the Chief Minister here in Canberra, took part in that rescue. He stripped off his clothes and swam in and rescued Duncan Patrick. Duncan Patrick's family and I commend Jon Stanhope and the others involved in that rescue for their brave efforts.

On the night of 18 January, because it was my birthday, we gathered to have a family party. That was the night of the big fires in Canberra. All of us are news junkies and we catch every news bulletin that we can, but that was the one night I had not caught up with the news bulletin, so I did not hear about the tragedy that had occurred in Canberra until the next morning. I was totally shocked. At that stage, they estimated that 400-odd homes had been lost. To me, as a person who had lived here and who knows the city well, I found it absolutely inconceivable that that could have happened in the year 2003.

When I got down here on Monday, I took a car and very quietly had a look at Duffy, Holder and Chapman. My late brother's wife lives on Gleneagles Estate in Kambah, and we visited her. We saw how close the fires had got and heard about the tremendous bravery and courage of people who were involved in that natural disaster. I join the Prime Minister and every other member of this House in commending the people who fought these fires and the property owners who stayed with their houses, foolishly or not. I believe the government should help in any way possible to restore Canberra to its pristine condition. It will be very difficult. There will be many things to consider. Naturally, the first thing you think about is whether these people were insured, whether they were covered for this and whether they can replace their houses. One person I was speaking to about the fires said, `Look, we weren't insured. I had to make a decision whether to insure or to feed the kids.' So not having insurance in some cases is not a case of negligence but a case of necessity. We have to be very cognisant of the fact that there are people who cannot afford insurance.

The member for Bass also said that this is not a time for recriminations, and it is not. It is not a time to blame people. The federal government does not have constitutional responsibility for a bushfire strategy; it has to be worked through in cooperation with the state governments. I will lend every resource available to me to encourage the government to work closely with the state governments to formulate a national bushfire strategy, but it cannot be done by the federal government alone. I do not want to see the state governments and the federal government finger pointing at one another. I think this has to be approached in a spirit of cooperation for the future. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion on bushfires which is before the House. I join with Labor leader Simon Crean and other members from this side of the House in offering our condolences to the people who lost family members during this bushfire season, not only in the ACT but in other states of Australia. We express our support to those who lost their houses and property in one of the worst fire seasons on record. As the shadow minister for regional services, territories and local government, with responsibility on this side of the House for bushfire policy, I have had the opportunity to view first-hand the devastation caused in many communities throughout Australia by bushfires this season. On 20 January, I visited fire-ravaged suburbs on Canberra's south side with the local member, Annette Ellis. I could not believe the devastation the Canberra fires had caused. Row on row of houses burnt to the ground, trees uprooted, burnt out cars and piles of ash and debris were all evidence of the sheer ferocity of the blaze that swept into the national capital.

speech.para: Barely one month earlier, with Simon Crean, in another part of the ACT, I launched Labor's national bushfire policy in an area that had been burnt out by the blaze that occurred over the 2001-02 Christmas period. Little did we know that four weeks later the national capital would be besieged on several fronts by fires that were both ferocious and devastating. The experience in the ACT has been replicated all over the nation, with community after community placed under threat by bushfires. As we speak, in my home state of Victoria there is news of new fire threats in the Western District and in other areas of the state. I know that the honourable member for McMillan, who will be speaking in this debate, has also experienced first-hand the devastation that has been caused by bushfire in his community and the stress that it places on those communities, not just in anticipation of the fire but in coming to grips with its aftermath. So far this summer, six Australians have died, over 600 homes have been destroyed and 1.7 million hectares have been burnt out. It has been one of the worst fire seasons on record and we are certainly not out of the woods yet. As we debate this motion in the House, firefighters in my home state of Victoria are preparing again to defend communities from bushfires.

I pay particular tribute to the personnel in the emergency services, who have the onerous task of defending life and property from fire. I refer to volunteer firefighters, members of the police force, ambulance drivers, defence personnel who were called in to assist, welfare agencies, government bodies at all levels and businesses. They have all done a magnificent job in responding to the threat and in coming to terms with the aftermath. They are genuine Australian heroes. Their commitment, skill, professionalism and sense of self-sacrifice and compassion deserve the highest commendation and praise. It is in the frontline when the bush is burning, or in the aftermath when lives and property have to be restored, that we see their great courage and compassion. It should be appreciated, admired and honoured, as we are doing in this debate on the floor of the House today.

May I, as I did earlier in this House, pay tribute to the firefighters of the Geelong region. On Australia Day, I left a function to go to CFA headquarters, where firefighters from the region were once again being dispatched to fight fires in other parts of the state. My mind travelled back to 1998, when a Geelong fire crew got aboard a vehicle in Geelong and travelled to the tiny town of Linton in the seat of Ballarat. Those firefighters never came home. I expressed the view in a debate earlier today that we do mourn the loss of the crew of the US space shuttle as it came back to earth—a crew that was manned not only by Americans but by people from other nationalities. It is right that we mourn those people who died in public service. But I would like to reflect today on a volunteer fire crew who in 1998 set out from Geelong to do their duty and protect their community and who never came home. There were five of them lost; a heavy blow to the Geelong community. I refer to the sense of trepidation of volunteers' families today: when the call is made, it is with a very real degree of uncertainty that they watch their loved ones go to fight these bushfires. As I said, they are the genuine Australian heroes, and we honour them in this debate in the House today.

Bushfires are a part of the Australian environment. In the history of Western settlement there have been occasions when the devastation caused by fire was profound: 1939, Ash Wednesday and of course this fire season are examples of that. It raises the question as to what ought to be an appropriate community response when these fires occur and when we seek to restore communities in the wake of those fires. There has been much debate about a national bushfire strategy. That debate was given impetus, in the wake of the 2001 fires, by the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and the now minister for regional services, who has responsibility in the government for coordinating the federal response to bushfires across the nation.

We had particularly bad fires in the 2001-02 season. On 11 January 2002, the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, called for a federal-state summit to coordinate services in the event of another fire disaster. I mention this because we did have the example—and it has already been alluded to in this debate—of the minister for regional services coming to Canberra in the context of those devastating fires, seeking to lay blame to score political points off the back of the devastation that had occurred. It was an inappropriate response which was roundly condemned—I think by all members of the Canberra community as well as the national community. It was not a time to be seeking to score political points or to be laying blame when sensitivities were at their highest.

I refer to the statement of the Deputy Prime Minister on 11 January 2002 simply because the federal government has called no summit. There has been no summit to discuss the issues that arose out of the 2001 experience. On 2 April 2002 the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government announced in a press release that the government was developing a national firefighting strategy in partnership with state and territory governments. No national firefighting strategy has been put to state governments or to the Australian people. The minister cannot walk away from the statements that have been made. I caution the minister and the government in the wake of these terrible events that they ought not to be making commitments that they do not intend delivering upon. Providing a contribution to the leasing costs of large aerial firefighting equipment is not a national strategy. The government has put in place elements of a national strategy, but it has not called a summit and it has not produced what it said it would produce.

I was particularly disappointed with the performance of the minister and the Prime Minister in the wake of the Canberra bushfires. The Prime Minister did tour the devastated areas offering comfort to those directly affected by the devastation. That is a right and proper thing for a prime minister to do and I commend him for coming off his holidays and doing that. But he described the bushfires as a strike against the national capital by the `summer terror'. We are not stupid; the Australian community are not stupid. It was a deliberate attempt by the Prime Minister to link his war on terror to the tragedies that were occurring. That attempted manipulation of the situation did not go unnoticed by members of this community. It is right and fitting for a prime minister to be at the scene of a tragedy such as this and to offer the comfort that he did. It is not appropriate for him to seek to manipulate that situation for another political agenda.

We have announced a national bushfire policy, in which there are several elements. We commend it to the government. It is in the process of ongoing development. We have pledged to increase aerial firefighting resources in line with what Australia's fire chiefs recommended to the government in advance of this fire season in the report that was handed down to the government in August last year, which has yet to be made public. We have proposed an Australasian interagency fire coordination committee modelled on the Canadian experience. I had dinner with the Canadian High Commissioner last night, where the issue of aerial firefighting resources was discussed. The Canadians have particular experience that I think we can learn from. In our policy we have supported a CRC and bushfire research, and we commend the government for making that commitment. We made it in 2002, immediately after the bushfires. The government made the financial commitment in December, and we commend them for it.
