We also included in that policy the protection of volunteers, because as we know there have been instances where volunteers have left their employment to fight fires and have suffered as a result of that.

In conclusion, may I offer this suggestion to the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, because there is a direct link between the impact of fires on communities and the tourism trade that goes on in those communities. In the last budget, the government provided $8 million over four years for the Regional Tourism Program and another $8 million for the See Australia program. I suggest to the tourism minister that the guidelines for these programs be reprioritised to give the regions hit by bushfires access to these funds. I also suggest to the minister that funding the redevelopment of tourist attractions be considered as a matter of priority. This would be something constructive which the government could do. I am sure those sorts of options are under active consideration, and they will receive my support. It has been a difficult season, and we are not out of the woods yet. Full marks to those in the front-line fighting the fires.

talk.start.para: —I visited a number of the worst affected areas in far-east Gippsland on Monday and saw first-hand the extent of the devastation of the bushfires. Gippsland has been fighting them for several weeks now, and they have hit with a ferocity that few could have imagined. I did not want to get into it straightaway, as I would much rather paint a picture of the loss of people's livelihoods and the trauma of communities, but the danger is ever present as, at the moment, to be frank, you cannot put this fire out. The firefighting experts, the agencies in control, advised me that it may well go all the way to the coast and not be put out until it hits the ocean. It is likely, as best as can be predicted, to go towards Orbost and Marlo. A large number of small communities are still under threat as we try to protect life and property.

speech.para: It will be a long campaign. People are now calling for inquiries and discussions about its causes. It is undeniable, if you talk to people who have lived in the area and worked the properties, that the build-up of fuel over many years is a primary cause. It is not the only one—freakish weather conditions and the long dry spell, which in Gippsland started in 1995 and has been interrupted by average rains only in 2001, also contributed. I do not think it is realistic to think that weeks can go by without community outrage over governments not addressing some of the root problems.

I tell you what: greenies had better not go to east Gippsland unless they are there to fight fires. People suffering the loss and hurt of fighting fires and putting themselves at risk—and incredible people from all over Victoria, South Australia, Queensland, New South Wales, New Zealand and America have flocked to east Gippsland to help to contain the fire; you cannot suppress it—are deeply resentful and they blame the greenies. Where are the greenies? I must admit that, for the first time, Senator Bob Brown is lost for words. When he is under questioning on this issue, he clams up.

talk.start.para: —He talks about Iraq.

—He talks about Iraq or anything other than the responsibility of extremist conservationists for bringing us to this point. It is simplistic to say that the failure of state authorities to reduce hazard over the years is the only cause, but it is just as ridiculous to say that it is not a major cause. The other thing that worries those in east Gippsland, as I found for myself, is that lessons are not going to be learned. Already the media caravan is moving on, and many parts of east Gippsland, where the worst devastation has occurred, are too far away from the media. They are not sending TV crews or radio journalists; only local newspapers are sending photographers or reporters. So they feel somewhat overlooked and they think—and it is not that they want this attention—that the corollary will be that the problems will not be addressed. They have never been addressed in the past. Every time there is a major fire—and the last one to compare this one with occurred around Wulgulmerang and Gelantipy in 1965—they say that no lessons are learnt. There was talk in the heat of the moment that there would be remedial action and that proper burning off programs would be done in consultation with the local community, and of course that did not occur.

speech.para: I think that is what is driving a lot of these calls for an inquiry now. If it is not done now, people are so cynical that, without media pressure and interest, state government authorities will be more interested in just covering up the lack of action in the past. I agree that we have to start the inquiry process now. I have come to this conclusion with careful thought, and it is only now, this week, that I think it will not be an insult to or a reflection on the firefighting authorities and the great men and women out in the field still fighting the fire if we have an inquiry. If we do not do it now, I think we will be letting them down, because we are all going to fall into the same trap as previously: a problem out of sight is a problem not addressed.

On Monday I toured Gelantipy, Wulgulmerang and Black Mountain and then drove across to Omeo, Benambra and Swifts Creek. When looking at the fire damage in Wulgulmerang, I saw hundreds of trees lying flat on the ground. They were sucked up by the ferocity of the fire. And let me put it plainly: the stomachs of cows were littered everywhere—because the cows had exploded; they have been buried but nobody is going to clean up the entire mess—and native animals were spread as far as the eye could see. With regard to the farmers, a large number of their paddocks had gone, their fences had gone and their haystacks had gone. Most were able to save their houses, but some of them are deeply traumatised. I know a large number of them. In fact, I was shown around the area by Paul Sykes. I met people like Peter and Sally Moon and Dave Woodburn, most of whom have suffered severe loss. It is incredibly difficult for them.

When I went across to Omeo and Benambra, large numbers of stock losses were suffered and thousands of hectares were burnt out. It is incredible that the town of Omeo is being threatened for the third time. It has really been attacked, and you see that it is surrounded by burnt land. If the winds come back, Omeo and the small township of Benambra will again be at risk. I was in Omeo before the first burn on Australia Day, and I thought that once the bush surrounding these towns was burnt they would be right, that the paddocks on the southern and south-western sides would be okay. But, no, this fire took on a life of its own and spread like liquid across paddocks where there was no grass. It skipped from piece of straw to piece of straw, and so you see these thousands of hectares of burnt paddocks which were in dry or drought conditions. It is extraordinary. There is no such thing as a firebreak with this fire. It skips rivers and paddocks—hundreds of metres where there is next to nothing. It is like liquid being poured across bare dirt.

We are at the mercy of the wind. At the moment, luck is favouring us and the fire is contained. It just burns away in the mountains. Once the wind whips up, it will threaten to descend onto communities. The towns currently under threat—and they are small towns or a collection of houses and farms making up a community—include Bendoc, Bonang, Buchan, Dargo, Goongerah, Swifts Creek and Tubbut. In a worst-case scenario, large towns like Orbost, with 3,000 people, and Bairnsdale, with 15,000 people, will be under threat. No-one in East Gippsland is insulated from the threat of this massive fire, the likes of which we have not seen for decades. They are once in a lifetime weather conditions, sure, but the fuel store is greatly adding to the extent and fierceness of the fires.

In those areas in my electorate that have already experienced fire—Anglers Rest, Benambra, Bunbar, Cobungra, Delicknora, Gelantipy, Omeo, Seldom Seen, Tongio and Wulgulmerang—the firefighting effort is inspiring but, nonetheless, they are weary. The department of sustainable environment, the department of primary industries, national parks and the emergency services can rotate their people. They are doing a brilliant job, are incredibly dedicated and are away from their families for long periods of time. They are drawn from throughout Gippsland and from throughout the state. But, for the locals who are fighting the fires themselves, this is their fourth week and they are exhausted mentally and physically. One issue—it is not one for discussion now, but eventually we will have to discuss it—is making some payment to these self-employed small business people and farmers who receive no remuneration. The issue of paying volunteers is a very complex and very sensitive one, but I think the strongest case could be made out for those people who do not have an employer. They are community people fighting in a long campaign.

We have not had a campaign of this duration in Victoria for decades. Normally, they are fires of two, three or four days, but the logistics of this are extraordinary given that close to a million hectares have been lost in Victoria to the three fires that have joined to form the Bogong complex. It stretches from Mount Buffalo in the west to the New South Wales border and to near Deddick in east Gippsland. Thousands of personnel are working on the fires: 1,900 from government agencies, a large number of local CFA, approximately 1,500 Country Fire Authority volunteers from outside the region, 120 Army, 120 South Australians, 70 Queenslanders, 35 New Zealanders and 35 from the United States. Over 30 aircraft are being employed, including a Navy Sea King helicopter and an Army Iroquois helicopter. There are over 100 bulldozers, many of them from the timber industry. The state government in Victoria is winding down the timber industry, and yet here they are at the front line, fighting these fires to protect communities. Two hundred and fifty specialised vehicles are currently active. There is a major commitment from all of Victoria—especially from Gippsland communities, including the timber communities—and from interstate.

Telstra has been very good. It has provided satellite phones in a number of the areas where there has been a loss of communications. I wish to pay tribute to Peter Ward and Countrywide, based at Sale. Peter Ward is an Omeo boy, so he has got family there. He has got a deep commitment to Gippsland as a whole but, no doubt, in his heart of hearts, to the Tambo Valley especially. I thank him and his staff for what they have done. I have also seen TXU, the electricity people, crisscrossing east Gippsland in convoys of trucks. They have been brilliant. They have very quickly restored power, and they have needed to. Over 150 power poles have been replaced, 65 linesmen and six site managers have worked throughout this period and 52 trucks and other vehicles and equipment have been used. They have brought in generators for communities as a temporary measure if need be. I thank them for what they have done. They have got communications to affected communities and farmers.

There is a dilemma for us because this is an incident still occurring and so all of our efforts are towards fighting the fire, but the fact is that recovery has got to take place as well. Farmers have lost heavy numbers of stock—thousands of sheep and thousands of cattle—thousands of hectares of land and hundreds of kilometres of fencing. We cannot just wait for the fire to be extinguished, probably by nature, eventually; we also have to start helping these farmers. The state government is now moving to help. Thankfully, the state government has announced that $500,000 will be provided for fodder, because otherwise cattle will starve. Fencing is an issue; replacement of fencing is essential. There will have to be some counselling too. I am speaking to federal agencies about what we can do. A number of the people I met are struggling to cope with the situation. We must address that. Insurance companies and banks had better not play ducks and drakes on this. They normally do not. During the drought, I thought the banks, after a slow start, were especially good. The insurance companies have been good after floods in Gippsland in the past, but we will be dealing with them as well to ensure that their customary support for people in emergency and crisis situations is continued in this instance.

There are many people whom I could mention. I came away feeling pretty proud to be an Australian. No-one complained. There were specific requests as I toured the fire areas on two occasions. But the worst occasion was last Monday. People are stoic, but they are shocked by the extent of their losses and worried about starting again. The Tambo Valley covers Ensay, Swifts Creek, Omeo, Benambra and beyond. In the last decade, there has been a collapse in wool prices and Ovine Johne's disease has devastated the industry. They have had drought, floods and now bushfires—yet there is no whingeing. The farmers have made a constructive response to the latest losses and the emergency, and they are already looking ahead. But we cannot let them down at this time of immediate emergency. We cannot let them down in trying to minimise, as far as human hands can, the risk of bushfires in the future.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to rise in support of this motion on the bushfires. On behalf of the people of the electorate of Wills, I extend my sympathy to the victims of these tragic bushfires—the families of people who have lost their lives and also the many families who have suffered through property loss. In some cases they have lost their livelihoods. They have lost their memories, their history and their past. One of the most graphic examples of that, here in Canberra, is the famous marathon runner Robert de Castella who lost his house and property and all the memorabilia which came with it. I was astonished by his mental toughness. When confronted with loss, he said, `That's just too bad; life is going to go on. I'm going to start again.' I suppose you do not get to be a successful marathon runner without that element of mental toughness, but it was astonishing and remarkable to see. I extend my sympathies to all the victims of the fires.I also wish to praise, as other have done, the efforts of our firefighters. They show colossal courage in the face of bushfire threats. They certainly risk their own lives; there is no question about that. What they do is breathtaking. We are all very much in their debt.

speech.para: We have had a lot of comments about the causes of the bushfires and implications for future public policy. In my view, some of those comments were inappropriate, particularly those made by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Mr Tuckey, as the fires were being fought here in Canberra. He was transparently seeking to score political points. Many people have condemned his interventions, I think rightly. Nevertheless, there needs to be a debate about the causes of the fires and we need to know what the lessons are for public policy. I certainly intend to be part of that debate.

The first thing we need to recognise is that the bushfires expose the contempt held by a number of people in the Liberal Party for protecting the environment of our children through the creation of national parks. It was not only federal Minister Tuckey who engaged in these kinds of comments. Minister Macdonald and Parliamentary Secretary Entsch advocated the clearing of forests as the solution to bushfires. As soon as you scratch below the surface, their hostility to national parks comes out. Frankly, if ministers of the Howard government seriously believe that the answer to bushfires is to cut down or burn our forests then we had better hope that there is a good export market for salt. We have already seen, through excessive land clearing, massive salinity problems in this country. If you want to keep it up, you will turn Australia into one big salt mine.

Transparent attempts to blame the states and territories for the bushfires have been nothing more than political opportunism, and they also fly in the face of the Prime Minister's stated aim that there should be no finger pointing. Increasing the rate of land clearing or destroying the habitat of our unique wildlife is not the answer, nor is blaming someone else. No-one would deny that carefully implemented fuel reduction burning is important. I certainly support an inquiry into bushfire prevention—I think that is absolutely appropriate—but the real political lesson to come from the bushfires is that it is time that we got serious about climate change. We have research from the CSIRO and elsewhere showing that human induced climate change will result in more frequent and more severe bushfires. The research shows that in much of the country rainfall is predicted to decrease and evaporation rates increase, causing vegetation to dry out, increasing the fire danger in all locations and increasing the number of days of very high and extreme fire danger.

The Howard government needs to factor the cost of climate disasters like drought and bushfires into its modelling of the costs and benefits of curbing our greenhouse emissions. If it did so, the benefits of being part of global action to tackle climate change would become obvious. I believe that, more than ever, it is time for the Howard government to ratify the Kyoto protocol on climate change, urge the United States to do likewise and intensify its efforts to curb and tackle climate change.

In 2002 we experienced Australia's hottest year on record. Unusually high temperatures, low rainfall and high evaporation combined to make this a very bad fire season—clearly the worst in at least 30 years. Our hot and dry conditions are consistent with predictions for climate change from greenhouse gases. Globally, 2002 was the second hottest year on record, and the 10 hottest years since records began—back in 1880—have occurred since 1987. This matches CSIRO predictions of an increase in Australian average temperatures by as much as six degrees by 2070 because of climate change. The CSIRO has predicted that the mean fire danger index will increase by 10 per cent if carbon dioxide concentrations double, which is what is predicted by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

In my own state of Victoria, this means twice as many very high and extreme fire danger days each year. Most fire damage, including loss of life, property, farmland, flora and fauna, occurs on those few days per year of high fire danger and in the few years per decade when fire danger is at its highest. The CSIRO is saying that climate change may lead to a doubling of the number of very high or extreme fire danger days. Similarly, I recently noticed Roger Stone, head of the United Nations climate applications research group, pointing out that Australian bushfires are associated with the El Nino conditions which developed six months ago. He noted the impact of the El Nino effect—of more fires caused by increased temperature, lower rainfall and stronger winds in these types of climate patterns—and noted that climate change could increase the fire risks. When the Howard government sits on George Bush's lap, it condemns our farmers to more bushfires. We have also noted the Insurance Council saying that the cost of the homes destroyed in the ACT—and I think this is an initial estimate; we may well find the figure increasing—will be $100 million.

There are issues arising here concerning fire management, and other speakers have spoken of these matters. I am certainly supportive of fuel reduction burning. That needs to occur. It is a complex issue. I note that a group of 16 Australian scientists, the spokesperson being the Dean of Science at Wollongong University, Professor Rob Whelan, is saying that we need to be careful about knee-jerk reactions. Professor Whelan said:

quote.para: National parks are not the reason for these fires. More extreme hazard reduction in forests will not guarantee protection from fires in severe conditions, but will threaten biodiversity.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: To suggest that these fires would not have occurred if there were fewer national parks is a ridiculous proposition. These fires have already burned vast areas of grazing, pasture, plantation and native forest land, as well as national parks.

speech.para: Similarly, I point out in relation to the issue of fuel reduction burning that there is no one right answer for any given area of land. Research carried out into fires that occurred prior to European settlement—and, of course, they did occur prior to European settlement—suggests that the interval between fires in dry sclerophyll forests, for example, was as short as three years. In a lot of typical eucalypt forests, it was every three years that a fire would occur. But fires in mountain ash forests on the mainland had an average fire interval of 100 years, and the average fire interval for temperate rainforests in Tasmania may have been 300 years. So there are different situations, and clearly the fuel reduction burning needs to have regard to that.

I also note the comments made by the Minister for Science, Mr Peter McGauran, who talked about the fires in Gippsland taking on a life of their own, skipping across the paddocks and skipping across the grass. He said:

quote.para: There is no such thing as a firebreak with this fire ... We are at the mercy of the wind.

speech.para: It is a very interesting observation that has also been made in relation to the Canberra bushfires, where you had very serious bushfires coming out of the pine plantation at Mount Stromlo and bushfires coming out of grassed areas, with embers going from the grassed areas onto houses and indeed from houses onto other houses. So to say that the solution to this is to clear everything and that will stop the fires is simply wrong.

I want to praise the government for the fact that it announced in December a new national Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre, based in Melbourne, which will bring together fire researchers from across the country to investigate better ways of preventing and controlling bushfires, particularly at the urban-rural interface. That is very important work. I believe that the expertise in the CSIRO Forestry and Forest Products division needs to be brought to bear on this issue. Researchers there have developed models of firebrand behaviour to predict spotting distances from different sources of burning bark under various weather conditions, and they note that some of these things can spot up to five kilometres ahead of the main fire, for example. They have also been involved in carrying out studies of the impact of fires from various causes. For example, a recent study in Victoria suggested that biodiversity is currently suffering from too much fire around settlements and too little fire in many forests and national parks.

It is therefore a question of getting the right balance to support Australian ecosystems. It is far from simple: some species like a lot of fire and some species do not like much at all. In the Blue Mountains National Park, west of Sydney, the dry eucalyptus forests that crown the ridges and blanket escarpments are regularly singed by bushfires but, if you go deep into the gullies and the rainforests, the Wollemi pine survives in those areas only by rarely encountering fire. Optimal fire regimes need to take that into account. They do not simply involve prescriptions of fire frequency and intensity: burning should be patchy and there needs to be a balance of young and old vegetation. One of the researchers, Mr Tolhurst, studied the impact of fire on different parts of the Wombat State Forest, which is north-west of Melbourne, and he concluded that generally ecosystems recover within two years as long as they are not entirely razed. Mr Tolhurst said:

quote.para: A key conclusion from our study was that recovery from fire is rapid provided there are small unburnt patches left behind.

speech.para: Another point I want to make in this debate is that a tremendous amount of fire occurs in Northern Australia. Dick Williams, an ecologist with the CSIRO in Darwin, says that more than 30 million hectares of bush go up in flames every year in Northern Australia—much more than occurs in the south—and yet these fires do not attract the same interest from politicians as fires threatening southern cities. I want to put on record my concern about the amount of burning that occurs in the Northern Territory. It seems that the frequency and intensity of bushfires in Northern Australia have increased substantially since European settlement and this is rather different from the pattern of burning that occurred when Aboriginal people used fire to stabilise what is an incredibly flammable and unstable environment. So we have got a disturbed equilibrium up there and I think it is something that needs to be examined.

In relation to fuel reduction burning, it may well be that we need bigger firebreaks and bigger buffer zones between national parks and areas of settlement. But, noting the observations I made before, it is no guarantee that we will prevent fires on private property. We need to understand that as many fires burn into national parks from outside as burn from national parks into the other areas. We need to look for science based solutions. Finally, we need to understand that we do live in a dry, bushfire prone country and we will inevitably experience fires. There are only two or three other countries or locations around the world that are as bushfire prone as ours. Certainly, we need to take all the precautions we can to minimise the damage caused by bushfires, but we also need to understand that this is the nature of the continent on which we live and that from time to time bushfires will be inevitable.

talk.start.para: —I think Mr Kelvin Thomson's speech is another example of the urban community giving advice to the bush, to people who have lived there for hundreds of years. These are generations of people who have had to manage their environment, who protect their property and who are some of the greatest environmentalists the nation has, because they are reliant on their environment for their income. They must look after that environment. The posturing of urbanites as to what is good for the bush, how fires should be managed and the sudden expertise such people have gained is just incredible.

speech.para: In my area, we lost 41 homes to a wild bushfire, and that was before Christmas. We regularly have bushfires in our area. Our community lives with bushfires and has a very comprehensive rural fire service. I know the people of my electorate of Mitchell would wish me to extend our sympathy and support to the people and residents of Canberra with regard to what has happened to them. It is a terrible thing to lose your life's treasures and probably the largest investment most Aussies make, their home, when a fire takes hold and destroys your property. It is very sad and traumatic and it takes a long time to recover from that. The people in my district are only now, some two months later, starting to get on with their lives, to rebuild and reconstruct their homes and to look to the future.

I have to say that I agree with the Minister for Science: I do not think that a delay in having a look at the causes of these fires and how we might better manage them should be delayed. I notice the Victorian government is not delaying the inquiry into the train disaster. We have lost many more homes. Two lives were lost in my area, though none were lost here. When a serious thing occurs, to delay an investigation is not a good thing. Information needs to be gathered while it is relevant and fresh in people's minds. We have not concluded the fire season at this point, so there is a limit to the extent of an inquiry and it would be a shameful thing to pull people off the fire front in order to take part in an inquiry. However, I believe that the framework can and should be set in place while all of the occurrences are fresh in people's minds.
I refer the House to a publication of the New South Wales government, which is entitled Burning question: the rationale and the problems. This booklet commences by saying:

quote.para: Every year in Australia, thousands of hectares of native bushland and crops are destroyed by wild fires. Damage to property and, tragically, the loss of lives does occur. Land managers and fire authorities must therefore look to practises that minimise the impact of fire on the community.
Many strategies have been considered and tested over the years to effectively reduce the number, frequency and severity of fires.

To minimise the adverse impact of bush fires, land managers and fire authorities have to consider the three concepts of fire: prevention, mitigation and suppression. The problems associated with each of these concepts are explored in some detail. Each have their problems and limitations. Reliance on one of these concepts alone will not necessarily achieve the required outcome.
The one strategy that has been the most effective is that of fuel reduction.

speech.para: This booklet then goes on to explain the processes and the reason why fuel reduction should take place. This is a publication from the New South Wales government; it has the logo of the New South Wales Rural Fire Service on it. It is a government publication and this is what the New South Wales government has been saying.

People like Bob Brown do not count that sort of thing as being valuable. Bob would like to stop dams being built and then complain when houses burn down because we cannot put the fires out. It is illogical. There must be a proper scientific approach to these things. It is just madness to oppose everything that, with a rush of blood, you suddenly want to oppose. Bob was opposing dams and logging and the use of timber, but now he is opposing a potential war in Iraq because that is a politically wise thing to do. I suggest that as soon as the Iraq matter is over he will find something else that he thinks it is popular to oppose.

It is really quite illogical to say that these difficult issues should not be tackled by government. I think the apologists for the state governments in the Australian Labor Party would be better off in trying to come to grips with these issues. Governments have to make decisions and people in the National Parks and Wildlife Service and similar services offered by state governments need to resolve these factors and need to be up front about doing it. There is no reason why we cannot work through documents such as this one and find out why it was in New South Wales, for instance, that the legislation allowing for the management of national parks was not passed until 21 August, a time too late in the season for any preventive burning to be done. The dereliction of duty by the state governments and their failure to focus on the tasks and on these issues must be part of the examination that takes place.

It seems to me that we need to be careful, both for good management and for sensible retention of flora and fauna. From the fires in my district, the intensity of the heat and the speed with which the fires travelled, millions of trees will not recover. Usually, after a bushfire, trees will recover. Thousands and thousands of native animals were destroyed—wombats and wallabies—and bird life of all types because of the extent of the fire and the speed with which it travelled. If we can do anything to prevent that, we will be taking a commonsense interest in our environment. Those are the arguments that the Australian Labor Party choose to misrepresent by saying that we want scorched earth and concrete over Australia. That is not the case. There is no better conservationist than the man on the land.

In today's Herald Sun there is a little story that captures the attitudes of many people in the bush and many people familiar with fighting fires. It is the story of cattleman John Rogers. For 20 years John Rogers has been asking public servants to do something about the build-up of fuel in the Alpine National Park next to his farm. They refused. The article says:

quote.para: Six years ago, Rogers decided he'd had enough. So he set fire to a bit of the park in a classic fuel-reduction burn, the kind of thing some country fire brigades have demanded Parks Victoria and the Department of Sustainability and Environment do much more of.
But for trying to burn himself some security, he was taken to court and made to pay almost $2000. And the park next door never did get all the fuel-reduction burns it needed.
Now John Rogers, punished for trying to protect a bit of forest—and his farm—has seen that same forest go up in a terrible wildfire, just as he'd always feared.
And, also as he'd feared, his farm went up with it. All he saved was his house. Four sheds, tools, miles of fencing, pasture and a dozen cattle—all gone.

speech.para: That is the problem we are confronting and that is one thing that we need to deal with effectively. The people in my district have expressed their appreciation in functions held at Galston last weekend and a few weekends before at a function held at Glenorie, where funds were raised in large amounts. Thousands of dollars were contributed by people to assist those who had lost their property. Included were the clubs of the district: the Glenorie RSL Club, the Galston Memorial Club, the Dural Country Club and Castle Hill RSL. I start on a dangerous course in trying to mention the organisations that have come together to assist those who have lost their property. Fundraising has gone on and fire brigades are now looking for additional equipment, some of which is to replace equipment which has been lost but also to supplement the functionality of their sheds and their units.

We were most fortunate in our district to lose just 41 homes. It could have been hundreds; it could have been much worse than Canberra. Fortunately, the weather and wind conditions were such that the fire was able to be contained. It did not move south. It moved across the top strip of Sydney, burning an area of roughly 50 kilometres by 50 kilometres. There were approximately 1,500 firefighters involved in the event and probably 200 firefighting units—trucks and equipment—supported by men and women. All sorts of support units came out for food and emergency support, including the ambulance, the police, professional fire brigades, the SES—a great volunteer organisation—and of course the New South Wales Rural Fire Service. All of these people worked together to try to prevent things getting worse.

Today we are saying how much we feel for the residents of Canberra. I know my people would understand the feelings from this unexpected tragedy in the national capital. But they are saying, `Let's move on and start to do something about resolving this for the future.' They have heard for too long that they cannot do cold burns in national parks. They have heard for too long that sensible programs cannot be introduced. For too long they have heard, like cattleman John Rogers, that it is a crime to try to take preventive measures, but they also understand that the loss of millions of tonnes of timber and huge quantities of precious flora and fauna is not replaceable in the short term. They also understand that sensible measures that they have been practising for years, and which are now prevented by national parks and the state government, hold some of the answers that are needed in these circumstances.

I pay tribute to those involved in fire prevention, fire services and emergency services in our own district. We extend our sincere good wishes and support to the people of Canberra. I know that many people have come down here to fight the fires and give support to those in the Canberra district and in the Eden-Monaro area to the south. We need to start that inquiry and we need to be fair dinkum about it. We do not need to protect state authorities, even if they are run by the Australian Labor Party.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support this motion. The people of Gippsland are experiencing substantial bushfires in the eastern part of our region, as you would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker. It has been a very tough time for the people in East Gippsland. The fires have not just lasted for a day or two; we are now into the fourth week of fires in far-eastern Gippsland. A lot of people have been involved in fighting those bushfires, and a lot of people have been affected by the impact of those bushfires. For us in Gippsland, it has been a uniting experience, although it has been a terrible experience. Few people get to experience bushfires in their lives, but the people that you speak to who have experienced bushfires will tell you just how terrifying they are. The impact of going through it lasts forever.

speech.para: The people in East Gippsland have fought courageously against these bushfires. They have fought courageously to protect their communities and their livelihoods. They have not fought alone; they have been joined by family members and friends from right across the Gippsland region, from right across Victoria, from right across Australia and even from overseas. The people who live in my electorate have made a substantial contribution to fighting those bushfires in far-eastern Gippsland. We consider ourselves very much a part of the same region and, when our mates in East Gippsland needed help, people from my district were only too ready to lend a hand. A lot of CFA brigades from my electorate have been involved. A few that spring to mind are: the Drouin brigade, the Drouin West brigade, the Noojee brigade, the Moe brigade, the Warragul brigade, the Nilma North brigade, the South Drouin brigade, the Westbury brigade and the Newborough brigade. Those are just a few that spring to mind; there would be many others that have contributed to the fight against the bushfires.

Hundreds of people—if not more than a thousand—from my electorate have been directly involved in assisting the communities in far-eastern Gippsland deal with the bushfires. These people have contributed either through their volunteer services, through the CFA or by just going to those areas and lending a hand—being there to support the people, through the volunteer efforts of the various community groups which have been involved in helping the people who live down that way; or, in less formal ways, being a support to family members and friends who live in far-eastern Gippsland.

It has been an incredible time in the Gippsland region. There has been a climate of fear that I have never seen before in my life which has been created by the very real ongoing risk of bushfire. Every hot day that we have in Gippsland is a day when people in Gippsland think about what that weather means for the people fighting the bushfires in far-eastern Gippsland.

We also think of the risk of bushfires to our own towns and communities when we have that type of weather. We had a very real threat of fire in Morwell in my electorate. Mr Acting Deputy Speaker Adams, I know that you are familiar with our district, having been to the Latrobe Valley. This particular fire took place on the Princes Highway between Morwell and Traralgon, but on the east side of Morwell. You can see the impact of that very small fire every time you drive up and down the Princes Highway. It is a very real reminder of the bushfires which are taking place in East Gippsland and also in other parts of the country. The fire took place right next to the Energy Brix Australia briquette factory. It was right next to the timberyard of the Drouin West timber facility. It was right next to the open-cut mine of the Hazelwood Power Station. I mention the location only to draw to the attention of the House the significance of what would have happened had that fire got out of hand in that location.

Some people here may well remember when we had a fire in the open cut in the Latrobe Valley. The fire took a very long time to put out. It was a case of all hands on deck in the Latrobe Valley. Every able-bodied man in the Latrobe Valley stopped what he was doing and, with very rudimentary equipment in those days, battled those fires until they were put out. The risk is enormous with coal and timber. Energy Brix Australia's briquette factory has a lot of coal powder and coal fuel, as well as flammable liquids that are used for the maintenance of the facility.

We experienced a very real threat of bushfire on our doorstep in the Latrobe Valley and in other parts of my electorate. Our thoughts have been always with those people in our region who are going through enormous hardship and have showed enormous courage in dealing with the bushfires in East Gippsland. These are communities which are resilient and tough. These are people with whom we have had a long association. Many people from my electorate have family and friends who live in East Gippsland. For many of us, it is a place where we have gone for our holidays or which we have driven through as we headed up towards New South Wales and perhaps into Canberra or southern Queensland. These areas are well known to us, and the people are well known to us. They are our family members and our friends. Our thoughts have never strayed from them during these difficult times that they are experiencing.

The volunteers have done a wonderful job. They have shown enormous courage and enormous grit. They have been prepared to do hard things to protect their communities and to make sure that people in other communities do not lose everything they own—everything they have worked hard for. But we must not think only of the people who went to fight the fires; we must also think of the people who stayed behind. We must never lose sight of the fact that the people who stayed to protect their communities from the risk of a fire are just as brave and made just as big a contribution to the communities and regions in which they live. It takes a lot of courage to go and fight a fire, just as it takes a lot of courage to not go and to stay to protect your own community from the risk of bushfire. That is what happened right across Victoria. I want to say to those people who stayed behind: we know just how gutsy you were to stay and fight. We know just how special your contribution was, even though right now there might not be a bushfire in your own town or community.

When we talk about the volunteer firefighting effort, often the contribution of employers, in particular small business employers, is overlooked. I want to say sincerely to those businesses who let the Country Fire Association volunteers in their employ go to fight the fires: thank you so much for doing that. Thank you so much for making those people available to fight those fires because, without those people, communities would have faced up to those bushfires without the personnel they needed to fight that battle and to protect their livelihoods, their properties and the lives of their families and loved ones. I say to the employers who let go their people who are volunteers: thank you for doing that.

We are lucky in Victoria: in firefighting and emergency services we have a great partnership of full-time personnel and volunteers. We are also fortunate in Victoria to have a government which takes seriously the role of emergency services volunteers and which backs them accordingly. In Victoria, the Bracks government has contributed an additional $120 million over three years towards the CFA. I say to Steve Bracks and his team: well done. That work, that funding, that commitment and that belief in the importance of this area is so important right now. Often in political life you make a contribution and it does not get recognised. The contribution that the Bracks government has made to skilling up our people and making sure that they have the resources they need to fight these fires is very obvious—people in the community are getting a benefit from that right now.

In talking about the people who have made a contribution to handling the bushfires in East Gippsland, I want to place on record my absolute admiration for the work that ABC Gippsland radio have done in their coverage of what has been a very substantial disaster in our region. The courageous reporting of Mark DeBono, who has been with the people of far-eastern Gippsland at substantial personal risk to himself, in bringing news of those people to us has been incredible. The work of Kellie Wilson, who has been supporting Mark and the rest of the ABC team in bringing the news of the bushfires that are taking place in the east to the rest of Gippsland, has been fantastic.

We are very lucky in the Gippsland region to have Mark DeBono, Kellie Wilson and the rest of the ABC Gippsland team. They understand that it is our family and our friends in East Gippsland going through this crisis, and we want to know how they are going and what is going on. They have made sure that we have been informed, they have made sure that they pass on all the information they have and they have played a substantial role in assisting the emergency management people over there, by providing information to people who are at risk at the fire front and by helping to coordinate that volunteer firefighting effort. So I say a very big thank you to Kellie Wilson and Mark DeBono, from all of us in the Gippsland region. We in Gippsland owe you our sincere thanks for all your efforts and everything you have done in bringing us the news of what has been taking place in terms of the bushfires in East Gippsland.

I was at the Noojee Country Music Festival and Mountain Horse Racing event over the weekend. It is a great event—many thousands of people go there. This is the fifth year that I have gone and the fifth year that I have presented the trophies to the people who win the mountain horserace. When I was up at Noojee, I spent a lot of time talking to people from that district who work in the timber industry and who are involved in local firefighting efforts. Such an enormous number of people have made a contribution to helping with the fires in East Gippsland.

I felt so proud, as their local member, to represent such an amazing group of people—people who are not millionaires but who give their time so freely, people who do not have a lot but who give to others. The people who work in the timber industry and the people who live in Noojee, West Gippsland, the Latrobe Valley and right across the Gippsland region are an incredible group of people. I am lucky to represent them. I know how much the people who are now fighting the fires in East Gippsland appreciate the efforts of people from my electorate and from right across the country—in particular, other parts of Victoria—to make sure that their communities are kept safe. It has been a tough time for us, but I am enormously proud of the contribution that people in Gippsland have made to keeping other parts of our region safe.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to speak on this motion without closing debate.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Prime Minister's motion relating to bushfires. I join with the Prime Minister in extending the sympathy of the people of the electorate of Murray in northern Victoria, to all Australians who have suffered grievous, personal losses due to the fires in recent months. The extent of the loss of life and property in the ACT was particularly tragic. On behalf of my electorate of Murray, I also want to express concern and sympathy for those in Gippsland and, in particular, our neighbours in the north-east of Victoria—where dozens of small communities have been battling fires for more than a month, in conditions that frequently demand great personal courage and stamina. As I speak here today, there are north-east communities that continue to be on full alert—watching, waiting and activating their fire plans daily. The fires continue unabated and will not be quenched, it would seem, until we have a prolonged deluge. We just pray that this will come soon. Only someone who has experienced the intensity and terror of a raging bushfire can begin to understand what the communities still suffering are going through. Our thoughts are with them.

speech.para: I also want to acknowledge the excellent support of Goulburn Murray ABC FM radio. They have been broadcasting daily detailed and critical fire related community information for weeks now. Their producers and presenters have ensured communication between the communities, firefighters, emergency services, Bureau of Meteorology and countless volunteers and have delivered seamless information in a way that has helped maintain morale and a sense of community. People working together to survive the worst fires on record are grateful for this support.

I also want to sincerely thank all of the volunteers from the local country fire brigades—particularly Region 22, who have gone from the Murray electorate to the north-east to lend a hand. Members from over 80 of our rural fire brigades, 16 urban brigades and 10 groups have gone from the great flat plains, where irrigation channels often protect us, into the north-east forests and hills to lend a hand. Their effort has been outstanding and, as the Prime Minister's motion states, it truly demonstrates the strength of the Australian spirit.

Environment Australia has been updating me on the status of the fires. I think it is important to put this on the record so that future generations reading back to this time will understand the extent of the current disasters that are facing us. On 29 January, fires were still burning in Tasmania, Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, Northern Territory and Western Australia. The fires in southern New South Wales, alpine Victoria and Gippsland, in particular, still pose the greatest threat to property. The impact of the current fire season on the Australian Alps national parks, which stretch from Canberra almost to Melbourne, has been very significant. The fire front has stretched more than 200 kilometres from Mount Kosciusko to Mount Hotham. An area of over 750,000 hectares had been burnt by late January: with 380,000 hectares in New South Wales, including nearly half of Kosciusko National Park; over 420,000 hectares in the Victorian alpine area; and much of the ACT, including 80 per cent in the Namadgi National Park and the Tidbinbilla nature reserve.

The extent of the area burnt has exceeded that of the Ash Wednesday fires of 1983—when over 100 fires in Victoria burnt about 210,000 hectares and over 2,000 houses were lost—and so far it is half the area destroyed in the 1939 fires. From December 1938 and to January 1939, fires burnt 1½ million to two million hectares in Victoria alone. Back in 1851, fires covered a quarter of what is now rural Victoria—approximately five million hectares were burnt, we are told, and it killed over one million sheep. So we are not strangers to fires in this country, but the devastation is nonetheless very severe and involves great personal trauma.

Since 1 January 2003, fires started by lightning have burnt over 17,000 hectares in the Blue Mountains National Park, part of the Greater Blue Mountains World Heritage Area. At this stage, it is impossible to quantify the cost to the nation of the assets that have been burnt. Of course, fires are a natural part of the Australian landscape. We live in a fire-prone environment, with periods of peak fire danger occurring in particular seasons in all parts of the continent and Tasmania. The sustaining of much of our unique biological megadiversity is dependent on a regular, but not too frequent or intense, burning regime.

Australia's Indigenous owners developed systems of highly effective fire management to modify and sustain the landscape in order to regenerate and increase their food supply. Fire was also used for communication and improving travel routes. Indigenous societies also knew the importance of reducing fuel loads from time to time to lessen the risk of more intense destructive wildfires that killed rather than regenerated species.

We are now in the midst of a very extensive and prolonged drought. This has been accompanied by some of the highest temperatures on record, and these circumstances have combined to create this extreme fire risk and outcome. They have resulted in some of Australia's most extensive and destructive fires. The last time we saw such devastation was in the fire disasters in New South Wales during the terrible drought of 1901. All the fires have not yet been put out, and it would seem that they could be as severe as the fires of 1926 and 1939.

Contemporary fire management, particularly the use of cold burns or prescribed burning to reduce hazard and for biodiversity conservation, is complex and controversial. When the last fire is out and everyone has had time to recover, public land managers, policy makers and experts need to sit down and analyse the behaviour of the fires in areas treated differently in terms of hazard reduction and other fire management efforts. The John Howard-led government has committed $25 million to the new Commonwealth Bushfire Cooperative Research Centre. This was announced just last year. Participating agencies include the Bureau of Meteorology, state and territory land management agencies and fire authorities, the CSIRO, universities and Emergency Management Australia. Obviously, that CRC will have very important work to do.

In the wake of the recent disasters, some have called for a national inquiry into bushfire prevention. Assessment of the environmental impact of the 2003 fires will require evaluation of firefighting strategies. Mechanical intervention using earthmoving equipment, back-burning and the use of fire retardants play an important role in wildfire suppression, but we need to better understand the environmental impacts in the short and longer term. We also need to note where the fires began. At this time, a lot of people are focusing on national parks or state parks and their fire management regimes. Interestingly, the New South Wales fire service reports that, recently, less than 10 per cent of the fires that started in national parks moved outside them. Twenty-four per cent of fires in parks started outside them and moved into the parks. Alarmingly, 21 per cent of these wildfires were caused by lightning but the rest were caused by arson or suspected arson. Most of these fires could have been avoided, and this is a shocking statistic. It would seem that, while many Australians risk their lives to save others in fires, there are too many other Australians with criminal intent prepared to put lives, property and biodiversity at risk.

Fireproofing our great country is not possible—and, besides, many ecosystems have evolved to depend on fire for regeneration—but perhaps we are moving into a new era where the new Bushfire CRC will be covering new ground with the research it will undertake. I am referring to climate change. In 2002, Australia's Third national communication on climate change reported that the incidence of wildfire in Australia could be expected to increase with global warming. The number of days of extreme and high fire danger could be expected to increase. Insurance and finance industries are re-evaluating risks associated with insurance in light of changing climate and projections of increased property damage through events such as fire. Possible responses by insurance companies to an increase in the frequency of such events include raising premiums, restricting coverage and withdrawing from some areas of insurance with the highest risk. Obviously, any such decisions will have significant economic and social ramifications. We also have to take serious action in terms of our public lands. The interim report of the Independent Scientific Committee on An assessment of the values of Kosciuszko National Park noted in a chapter on fire:

quote.para: Specific areas prone to high-intensity wildfire can be accurately predicted, so it is possible to preclude developments and investments in these lands, by using restrictions similar to those applied in areas subject to other natural hazards such as flooding and landslip ... Such measures could include:

speech.para: strategic fuel reduction (including prescribed burning) ... ;
exclusion of residential and other asset development in fire prone lands;
making assets fire resistant;
ensuring that those involved in fire management have a basic understanding of fuel dynamics and fire physics ...

All of this work needs to be done, and I am sure it will be. Certainly a one size fits all strategy cannot be adopted for fire in Australia. The extensive annual controlled burning for ecosystem management in Kakadu, for example, is quite different from the fire strategies which are aimed at protecting people, plants and infrastructure in the Australian National Botanic Gardens. Fuel loads and fire behaviour are influenced by many factors, including the structure of vegetation cover, weather, the terrain and the history of land management in the area. However, the interactions between type of fuel, temperature, wind speed and direction, and fire spread can mean that—despite the very best efforts of firefighters on the day, the forward planning of land managers and the fire plans of householders—a tragedy like the ACT fires can still occur. A city fringe wildfire in gale force winds, in tinder-dry drought conditions and with temperatures like the temperatures this January will inevitably be disastrous.

I also wish to refer to the role of the Bureau of Meteorology as it struggled to keep up with the demands of so many fire fronts and the increasing need to do more accurate forecasting to assist in the firefighting effort. They coped with the demands in a magnificent way. I am proud to report the accuracy and the speed with which they were able to assist the firefighting effort with forecasting. In particular, the Victorian Regional Forecasting Centre has been working seven-day, round-the-clock shifts. To give you one example of the intensity of their work, on 15 January there were eight uncontrolled fires, 28 fires contained and 65 fires controlled, mostly over north-east Victoria in mountainous terrain. Forecasting was required for all of those fire fronts and in conditions where often, for example, the winds blowing in the valleys were blowing from a different direction to the winds at the top of the mountains. In addition to forecasting accurately in a timely manner for the firefighting, because of the smoke and haze, aviation forecasting has also been a particular challenge. The Bureau of Meteorology has been performing magnificently to ensure the greatest possible public safety.

I want to repeat that we are in difficult times with our fires but Australians are not strangers to the devastation of fire in this country. Fire is a natural phenomenon. However, with human-induced global warming, we can expect more fires in the future. We need to understand those fires better, understand the needs of ecosystems and also understand the human psychology that puts some individuals with a matchbox in their hands beside a flammable heap of material in the bush, with no regard for the lives of their fellow Australians. I very strongly support the motion by the Prime Minister. We are a great country with great people. This fire season effort yet again demonstrates what real Australians can do.

talk.start.para: —Once again, this summer we have seen enormous devastation wreaked not only here in Canberra but throughout the continent. A couple of years ago Sydney was absolutely ringed by bushfire. Our biggest city, with the largest population, had at its very core bushfires of an intensity and immensity that could hardly be imagined. People found it very difficult to comprehend just how significant a natural force this was. Year after year, some years more than others, this has come to the fore.

speech.para: There have been responses to that over time. The latest response of significance was in 2002, when, after more than 100 years of this federal parliament, a specialist body was finally set up to have a look at the nature of bushfires from a federal perspective. In part, that is because responsibility for dealing with bushfires, controlling them and taking care of the environment locally has largely been put at the feet of state governments and of local council or shire bodies. What we do know is that it is fundamental that we have a Commonwealth research institute to look deeply into the very nature of the Australian landscape and how it has changed and that it come up with a better means of dealing with Australian bushfires.

I think the fundamental problem we face is very simple: we do not know very much at all about Australia's landscape and how it operates. Despite being surrounded by 600 different species of eucalypts, we do not understand their fundamental nature, we do not understand how they operate, we do not understand how to manage them and we do not understand how to live with them. And yet, at state and federal level, we have had public policy made that should be based on those fundamental understandings.

Looking at the early history of Australia, population from the West—from England—started here in 1788, after Cook's discovery 18 years earlier, after previous discoveries by other Europeans. From the evidence, it used to be thought that Aboriginal migration to and population of Australia occurred between 25,000 and 40,000 years ago. That was upped to probably about 60,000 years ago. There is some evidence that it could have occurred 100,000 years or so ago but, for most of the modern period—the period of homo sapiens—the Aboriginal people have been here and have managed the land. But, since 1788, the Australia that the Europeans came to has dramatically changed.

We know that there is far less forest here in Australia than when Captain Cook first sighted the shores of eastern Australia. We know that there is far less forest that is tropical rainforest based, because we know what was culled out of the northern part of New South Wales in the cedar-getting that was one of the first great industries in Australia. We also know that that has caused a dramatic change in the nature of the forests that are left, and it has in fact encouraged the takeover of those areas that were temperate or subtropical rainforest by eucalypts. We know also that, apart from the dramatic diminution in the extent of our forestation, it has probably changed.

Early on, when I was a history teacher dealing with the very early depiction of Sydney and the colony of New South Wales from 1788 to about 1810, there was a view prevalent that the Australia that Cook saw and that Phillip helped to establish a colony in was just the same as the Australia of today and that the bush then was the same as in the Australia we have today, except that there was more of it. It was thought by some historians, but certainly by art historians, that what was painted of early Australia—the depictions we got first from rough sketches by people on Cook's voyages and later in the works of Tench and others, and the very first representative pictures—emerged as being so different to what we know Australia to be because English people were doing the paintings.

The central idea was that you held within your head a certain view of what the environment was like. If you were Eugene von Guerard or one of the other early painters of Australia, the expectation was that you would paint a parklike depiction of Australia, with afforestation that had virtually no undergrowth but very short grass. That is an indication that these artists were prisoners of their ideas of what landscapes should look like because they came from England or the Continent. There is a very strong set of reasons why you would expect that to be true. But later evidence that was advanced helped, I think, to change the possibility in terms of that picture. The best expression of that was Robert Hughes's work—a major and monumental work on the foundation of the colony of New South Wales. That work provided the first information that there might be something more fundamental than that—that it was not just the way that Pieters saw the land. More importantly, in his work called the Future Eaters, Tim Flannery, an environmental biologist, put forward a different view not only of the operation of fire and the way in which the Australian landscape was managed and developed by the Australian Aborigines but also of the fundamental place of large marsupials in the control of that environment.

In an article a week or so ago titled `Bushfire of our vanities'—and I am indebted to the Parliamentary Library for finding this at very short notice—Flannery encapsulated the central argument that he put in the Future Eaters. He said that, instead of thinking of that environment, that parklike atmosphere of Sydney and its surrounds in 1788, as being an aberration, there is another explanation. The explanation is that, when the explorers—because it was not just the people drawing the pictures—said that they could walk through areas of Sydney that were virtual parkland, they meant it. They meant it because fire had been used to create an environment in which Aboriginals could hunt large and small marsupials through the grasslands. The dense nature of the eucalypt forest that we have around Sydney now was not the case in 1788. He makes the point in his article that Cook found a continent wreathed in fire from one end to the other. From Western Australia to the eastern seaboard, Australia was dominated by fire—probably not the raging fires that we see today but more controlled burns. It took most of our European history before we came to a fundamental understanding that we need to use Aboriginal methods of management to control the forest.

Based on the foregoing, I make this fundamental point: it is not wise of the government to rush forward and belt the daylights out of people who have argued for a green perspective on forest policy. No-one knows how we should properly manage Australia's forests. It is my inclination—I have argued it in the past—that we need to look extremely closely at this, because I do not think there is much sense in totally locking up all of our forested land and just letting it be. If we do, we would not be managing the land in the way it has been managed for millennia. That would allow a situation in which we would have the almost total devastation of our great forests and of our lands as a result of raging wildfires. The point that Flannery finally makes with regard to this is that it is not very smart not to take into account the fact that our settlements have moved directly into the path of our major bush areas.

We in opposition call upon the government to support the work of the Bushfire CRC in starting the fundamental steps to understanding the true nature of Australia's environment and the true nature of our bush. The government should not just run off in an ad hoc way and say, `Let's blame people because this stuff has been locked up.' It should look at different ways of managing our environment so that the inflammatory nature of the Australian bush and its eucalypts can be tamed to our purposes in much the same way that the Europeans tamed their environment in continental Europe itself.

talk.start.para: —I wish to express my deepest sympathies to those families who have been affected by bushfires and to those who are still battling blazes in south-eastern New South Wales and northern Victoria. I say that as one who was for a long time the captain of our local fire brigade in one of the worst bushfire areas in New South Wales, the Cobar Shire. When a fire really goes, it goes. I can remember in 1984-85 in the worst fires we had, three times in one day the fire went clean over the top of us. You cannot fight a fire in that situation. `Firefighting' is the worst explanation of what brigades do that I have ever heard. You set up defences and when the fire dies down you try to control it. I think the crux of the issue that we are discussing is the defences and the preparations you make to control fire.

speech.para: In New South Wales in particular, every year we wait with bated breath to see how the fire season will play out. This has been a particularly horrendous season, and it is far from over. In some areas the fire has been stifled by the drought. A lot of grassland has been eaten out and many areas will not carry fire at all. Luckily, in those circumstances there is insufficient fuel to be a danger to humans or to wildlife. But in forested areas the drought has provided fuel for the fires. The forest fuels are abnormally dry. The natural barriers like the moist swamps, the creeks, the rivers and the shallow lakes are simply not acting as they normally do.

Fuel is the most important element of a bushfire. Fuel determines the intensity, speed and heat of a bushfire. The important characteristics of a fuel that determine fire behaviour are the fineness of the fuel and the structure of the fuel bed. In actual fact, those things that lie on the forest floor or on the timbered country's floor are the things that will determine whether or not a fire gets going. Grass is obviously the simplest form of fuel. I have seen grassfires travel faster than human beings are able to get around them and, in mallee or timbered areas, far faster than the possibility of getting around in front of them were you so foolish as to try to do so. The forest litter bed is the part which is most important in determining how fast or where a forest fire will spread. Research has found that doubling the fuel in the forest will double the rate of spread and quadruple the fire intensity. Note that I am talking about what happens in forests, not on farmland and not on privately held land.

It is very easy to understand why people want to live in an idyllic forest-like area. They tend these days to want to build their homes in those areas. While I shudder when I see the danger that they put themselves in, it is easy to understand why they want to live in such areas. But it is the job of governments and authorities to protect people from that danger. For far too long, environmental correctness has been given precedence over safety, over human life and over the value of the assets that people in the community have and depend on. If the status quo continues, especially in New South Wales, we will simply see a repeat of this next year and the year after and so on. Systematically reducing ground fuel by prescribed burning—in other words, hazard reduction—is the only way to reduce the incidence and severity of bushfires.

It is impossible in a country like this to reduce bushfires to the extent that they are not going to happen. We live in a dry country; we accept the dangers that come with it, but there are limits. Reduction burning can obviously be unpleasant and it causes pollution to some extent, so there is a built-in political resistance to it—especially among those in the metropolitan areas. But simply standing around preserving aesthetic values comes at one heck of a cost. When the bushfires hit and homes in the outer regions suffer from them, very little resistance can be offered. It is too late to try to deal with a fire when it is on your doorstep. The only way we can deal with it is by prevention.

A senior principal research scientist with the CSIRO, Phil Cheney is one of Australia's foremost bushfire experts. He spent 40 years trying to convince Australians of the need for hazard reduction. In the last two summers, there has been an enormous loss of assets and an enormous loss of life. In New South Wales, even in the Goobang Valley in my own electorate, fires have led to incredible losses. They burned in the national park for a very long time and, as a result, we lost incredible amounts of farmland, stock and opportunities for people to earn their living.

So many people have been affected over the last 12 months. In October 2002, a lady was killed in Ballandean in south-east Queensland; also in October, a death occurred in Abernethy, near Cessnock in New South Wales; in December 2002, a man was killed north of Sydney; in January 2003, four people were killed in the Canberra fires; and, also in January, a man was killed north of Perth in Western Australia. The estimated cost of the Canberra fires alone now stands at nearly $300 million. Five hundred and thirty-odd houses have been destroyed, and 800 have been damaged. Twelve thousand hectares of pine plantations were destroyed. I could go on and on.

It is interesting to look at what has happened over the past few years—since 1997, in particular, when the Rural Fire Service legislation was introduced into New South Wales. Fire hazard laws were recently introduced by the Carr government subsequent to that, to give the New South Wales government or the Rural Fire Service greater powers to force landowners to clear their fire hazards. The only problem is that Premier Bob Carr did not introduce this until 1 August, and that is little use when the bushfire season started before that. I make the point now—and I will make it again later—that it was introduced only for landowners on private land.

Bob Carr conceded that there were problems with it addressing only private land-holders but failed to recognise the extreme shortfalls posed by the timing of his legislation. Even more, he failed to admit what the real danger is. The real danger to homes and to farmland is what comes out of national parks. To simply give power over all private land but not public land defies the laws of commonsense. Why do you give authorities power over those who have the most interest in safeguarding their assets, their families and loved ones and not give those authorities power to deal with those who have the least interest in the lives of others and their private assets and homes? It defies commonsense and it flies in the face of what has happened since 1997 in three bushfire seasons.

It is time to stop bowing to environmental correctness. Everyone wants to look after the environment and have a decent place to live, myself included. But preserving the status quo will cause more environmental destruction and actually go against what it is that Bob Carr is trying to do. What he is trying to do is preserve the vote of those in the cafe set in the metropolitan areas, who mostly do not have to deal with the issue; the rest of us do.

When you think of the number of lives lost, the houses destroyed and the thousands of hectares of good farmland burnt around national parks since 1997, it defies imagination. I would like to go back to 1997 briefly, because that was when the Rural Fire Service legislation was introduced. I was involved in trying to get some sense out of the legislation, which was not designed to give the ordinary person input into what should be done.

At that time, we tried to give ordinary people who live with and deal with fires an input and the ability to go to the minister to say when the processes of the ministerial advisory council were not working. But because the government and the commissioner—who is still the commissioner today—in New South Wales were terrified of anybody else having a direct link to the minister on fire procedural matters in New South Wales, they did a deal with the environment lobby in the upper house to prevent an alteration to that legislation which would have allowed those involved in the rural fire situation greater transparency and access to the minister. They did a deal with the environmental lobby, which meant that the threatened species legislation had to be taken into account by private land-holders, national parks and everybody who—if any law of commonsense applied—would do hazard reduction burning.

The result is what we have had—and what we told them we would have—since 1997: lives lost, incredible amounts of farmland lost and incredible numbers of houses lost around Sydney and Canberra. If you do not give those who are charged with looking after fire regulations or the practical aspects and processes of them—in the case of New South Wales, the Rural Fire Service—the power to control government, public or crown land as well as private land, you are not going to approach a solution to the dilemma of losing lives and property to fire.

Bob Carr catered to the votes of the extreme green environmental lobby and refused to give power over national parks to those who must have it. National Parks and Wildlife Service's job as they see it is to preserve the status quo. Not only do they block off entries; they fill in dams and do everything they possibly can to make national parks, in a sense, unattractive to humans. That obviously makes it a lot harder to go in there to travel around and find water when it has to be used. In the same way, they try to discourage animals from watering in parks but have them watering in the farmland outside. It is not conducive to public safety, nor to the assets of the rest of us.

I believe that those in charge of national parks are certainly very decent human beings. But until those who understand and are charged with the fire prevention safety of the state—and other states as well—are forced to do those things that have to be done to set up barriers against future fires, there is going to be no sense in it. I have had National Parks in New South Wales say to me, `We simply couldn't do fire prevention burning—it was too green.' Any farmer in Australia could tell them how to spray and burn within a week in any situation where it is too green—it is not hard to do. We need to have the willingness, the foresight and the long-term vision to do it in order to save lives and assets.

talk.start.para: —I start by saying that the comments that have been made by the member for Parkes are very important. In the aftermath of what is clearly a tragedy for many areas of Australia—many parts of New South Wales, Victoria and, particularly, Canberra—it is imperative that people look at the way we are going to avert any future tragedy. We need to ensure that we manage our parks and our bush in a way which will prevent or mitigate the likelihood of such occurrences happening again. It is critical for authorities and governments at every level to determine the best way to ensure these things do not occur. I do not think it is acceptable for people to rush to judgment. It is necessary that this matter is looked at dispassionately. Indeed, that can be done if there is goodwill; and it should be done.

speech.para: I was not listed to speak on this matter. I rise briefly to put on the record my appreciation of the SES and CFA in Gisborne and in other areas of the electorate of Burke, who were called upon to put out what ended up being quite minor fires in my electorate.
