Indeed, I record my appreciation of those volunteers and professional firefighters from the region who went to other areas to ensure that there would be critical assistance for the homes and the lives of people in north-east Victoria. To those wonderful volunteers and to all those people from my electorate who involved themselves and went to fight the fires in Gisborne or beyond their own areas, I say thank you very much.

talk.start.para: —Every summer in my electorate of Pearce, bushfires have devastated large tracts of land, destroyed homes, caused injury and on some occasions caused loss of life. This year has been no different. Bushfires have raged through various areas of the Pearce electorate, including Bullsbrook, Swan View, Lancelin and others. Every year the volunteer firefighters work with the community to prepare for fires and work hard to train and prepare their volunteer teams. I have been involved in these planning meetings to get an idea of what actually goes on; I know the tremendous work that goes into the planning meetings, where they put forward the fire prevention plan for the season. I have also observed the tremendous dedication of these men and women, who not only make themselves available to fight fires in my electorate but attend road accidents, clear firebreaks and plan fundraising events to assist them to meet their goals as they set out to minimise fires within the region.

speech.para: Every year I hear stories involving acts of kindness and bravery as these people go about the job of fighting fires. One year not so long ago, I recall that local identity Harry Gratte received severe burns fighting a fire in Whiteman Park, and in fact he still bears the terrible scars after a couple of years of skin grafts. Harry is a very experienced volunteer firefighter and every year for many years he has put his life on the line, fighting fires not only in my electorate but in other areas. This year Harry was very lucky to escape with his life. The fire swept over his vehicle and it was only his long experience and quick action that saved his life. However, he was very severely burnt.

On another occasion, I can recall sitting with Mr and Mrs Owston after fire swept through Wundowie and destroyed absolutely everything on their property: their home, their fences, their shed, their tools, their vehicles and their stock. Sadly, Mr Owston passed away just recently, but I shall never forget sitting with them on the back verandah, which was the only bit left standing, buckled and burnt, with a thermos of tea and Mr Owston giving an account of coming home, finding the property razed and then having to shoot 600 head of stock. These kinds of stories really bring home to you just how devastated people are when faced with these events. The loss of human life is bad enough, but people who work the land also feel it when they have to destroy their stock.

Every year these tragic events are punctuated with acts of kindness and bravery, and I must say the community always responds very generously. At the beginning of this year, a fire in Lancelin claimed the life of a young volunteer firefighter from my electorate. That firefighter was Mr Craig Sandy. He was a young man with everything to live for. He was a dedicated volunteer. Sadly, he was killed when three fire appliances crashed as a huge blaze swept through Ledge Point and Lancelin, about 127 kilometres north of Perth, threatening homes and everything in its path. Mr Sandy was the captain of the Ocean Farm Volunteer Bushfire Brigade and the first summer fire victim in Western Australia. I understand he was to be married on Valentine's Day, so my sympathy goes to his family and particularly to his fiancee. His death is a stark reminder of the risk that firefighters take in the voluntary work they do for the benefit of their communities.

The Lancelin fire was a particularly bad fire. There were 100 firefighters working to contain the blaze, and it swept through a large area and threatened homes. People had to be evacuated, and some homes were lost. Alan and Nola Armstrong, from Wanneroo, were at Seaview in their holiday house when they noticed the fire. They started to hose the fire down, but eventually they had to evacuate as the flames drew closer. Mrs Armstrong said that a volunteer firefighter gave her a reassuring pat on the shoulder and said, `Don't worry, we'll look after your house.' She said that they did and that it was really a fantastic effort. All the houses in Seaview were saved, and the firefighters not only threw all their energy into fighting this fire but used all the resources they possibly could to try to contain the fire. Their efforts were hampered when an emergency services communication tower was lost to the flames. They had a particularly difficult time. I congratulate them for the tremendous effort they put in.

With these tragic events happening every summer in Western Australia, particularly in the electorate of Pearce, we all watched with dismay as bushfires swept through other parts of the country, claiming the lives of other Australians. In Australia this year I understand that about 1.7 million hectares have been affected by fire and that about 550 homes were lost just here in the ACT. But, above all, it is the loss of people's lives that is irreplaceable. We can always rebuild, but the real tragedy is the lives that have been lost in these fires and the suffering and pain that that has caused so many families and members of the community. The events in the ACT were particularly distressing. I know that constituents in my electorate of Pearce would want me to extend their deepest sympathy to those families affected by this tragedy, and that sympathy comes with a real understanding of the devastation of fire.

I support the Prime Minister's motion to the House which he made on Tuesday. It extends sympathy to all who have suffered throughout Australia personal loss through bushfires and acknowledges the tireless efforts of many individuals, including the rural and metro fire brigades. In my electorate, we have countless small communities, each of which has its own bushfire brigade which is run on a voluntary basis. As I said, these people do not just go out and fight fires; they do lots of other emergency work. They attend country road accidents. They do a lot of work each summer, knowing the history and that bushfires occur every year, with the community in trying to minimise the risk to members of the community from bushfires. On top of that, they raise funds to help to keep their units going.

In his motion, the Prime Minister also thanked all of the emergency and rescue services and the ambulance service. In my electorate, which is made up of many small communities and country towns, this work is frequently done by volunteers. In fact, in the Pearce Australia Day awards, which I gave out, there were volunteer ambulance drivers and volunteer firefighters nominated by the community to receive awards. The Prime Minister also thanked Defence, the police, welfare groups, government agencies, councils and business. I want to pause just for a moment to say, again, businesses in the electorate of Pearce are extremely generous not only in providing equipment and donations but also in releasing their staff members to go and perform this voluntary work. That is a real contribution to the community and it sometimes goes unacknowledged.

I would also like to add the property owners to my list of thanks. I know that in my electorate and certainly in the ACT there were people who not only stayed to fight the fires in their community, trying to prevent their own homes from being burnt down, but when they had done that job, often having lost the battle and lost their own homes, then turned their attention to helping their neighbours save their homes and to trying to save community facilities such as schools and other community buildings. I think these people also need to be acknowledged. There would be nothing more devastating than to be there trying to fight a fire on your own property with your own home threatened, watching it burn down and then having to focus your attention on helping to save your neighbour's property or other community property.

I would like to thank the many Australian people who made offers of assistance, sympathy, goods, accommodation and moral support, which is really very important for the people who were affected by these fires. During the fires, because obviously most of us who travel to Canberra to serve in this parliament know many people who live in Canberra, I made a few calls to people I knew to find out whether they were safe. I was told by the people I rang that they had never seen a community pull together in the way that people did here in the ACT over the days following the fire. Friends told me that many families went to the supermarket and filled up the shopping trolley with the object of delivering those goods to people who had lost everything in the fire. This was quite a common situation.

There were countless stories of bravery, generosity and great kindnesses in the days following the fire. This is just part of the true Australian spirit. We can all feel very proud to live in a community where that community spirit is so evident and be enormously grateful for the kind hearts and warm personalities that I certainly encounter every day. We tend to be bombarded with all the bad things that are happening and all the negative accounts of what is going on in the community—robberies, old ladies being attacked and having their handbags stolen and houses being broken into—but we do not hear often enough about the tremendous acts of kindness and generosity and the unselfish actions carried out on behalf of so many in the community.

To all those who have lent a hand and who have helped the community in some way and particularly to the volunteer firefighters in my electorate, who have been absolutely tremendous, I say thank you. Once again, on behalf of the Pearce electorate, I extend my sincere sympathies to those in the ACT who have lost friends and family in the fire and to those of other states who have been similarly devastated.
Debate (on motion by Mr Murphy) adjourned.

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Disastrous bushfires have devastated not only Canberra but large areas of regional and urban Australia, while the unending drought brings ruin even to the best parts of our country. Once again, climatologists and CSIRO scientists are warning the government that the intensity and frequency of extreme weather conditions that provide opportunities for large-scale bushfires are directly linked to global warming, which is itself driven by greenhouse gas emissions.

speech.para: The evidence that the Prime Minister claims to have for the existence of Saddam Hussein's arsenal is far more tenuous than the evidence linking the drought and bushfires to global warming. And yet, despite a lack of any substantial evidence, the government is willing to spend billions of dollars to send troops to Iraq while at the same time it claims that Australia cannot afford to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. If the government can argue that spending large sums of money on a war in Iraq is justified because of the possibility of the existence of chemical, biological or nuclear weapons, why can it not find the same amount of money for the protection of Australia from the ravages of greenhouse gas induced climate change? There is no doubt that a significant number of the frail, the sick and the elderly will have died as a result of the extreme temperatures of recent times. This does not include those tragically killed in recent bushfires around Australia.

While the government cannot be blamed for these deaths, there is no doubt that they will bear a growing responsibility for future disasters if they continue to do nothing to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases. The evidence for the damaging effects of global warming continues to mount. The New Scientist of 18 January this year reports on new research that has uncovered a previously mysterious circulation pattern in the Pacific Ocean. Francisco Chavez from the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute has shown that the El Nino phenomenon follows a roughly 25-year cycle. The cycle alternates between many years with warm Pacific waters and strong El Ninos and many years with cooler waters and weaker El Ninos. In the years with stronger El Ninos, Australia experiences more severe droughts. Australia is presently in the grip of an unprecedented severe drought.

According to this new evidence, Pacific waters should be cooler and El Ninos should be significantly weaker. This tells us that a severe drought is not meant to be occurring at this time. Reviewing this new data, Frank Schwing of the Pacific Fisheries Environmental Laboratory in Pacific Grove, California, has speculated that global warming could spark a perpetual regime of severe El Ninos or `something even less welcome'. How much worse could things get?
In answer to my question on notice No. 1202 to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage regarding the cost of implementing the Kyoto protocol, the minister replied:

quote.para: ... the annual costs of implementing the Kyoto Protocol range from a low of 0 to a high of 0.4 per cent of GNP at 2012.

speech.para: The minister's own figures show that it would not significantly harm our economy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. These figures no doubt ignore the many savings that could be achieved if the analysis were not affected by the constraints imposed by the minister.

An underlying, if unstated, principle that is often used to justify government defence spending is that no matter how small the threat there should be no constraints on the money spent to meet that threat. Why is this government so inconsistent? Why does the government maintain a head-in-the-sand approach to our environment? For how much longer will this government ignore the very large threat posed to Australia by global warming caused by greenhouse gas emissions?

talk.start.para: —As I did this time last year in this parliament, I would like today to pay tribute to the special group of people who were recently presented with Australia Day awards in Dickson. All the people I am about to speak about have given much of their time and energy to the Pine River Shire, to their local community groups and to those around them. Their achievements are in areas that range from sport and music to culture and voluntaryrism. At a ceremony of over 500 people, with 119 new Australians receiving their citizenship, it was wonderful for these great Australians to be honoured in front of those who had just decided to make this country their permanent home. The spirit of voluntaryrism is well and truly alive in Australia today, and I am proud that so many of my constituents in Dickson are willing participants in a variety of voluntary organisations, sporting clubs and community services.

speech.para: The first person I would like to mention today is Mr Doug Dohle, the 2003 Pine Rivers Citizen of the Year. Doug is the current president of the Pine Rivers Pony Club. As his wife and daughter will both tell you, Doug devotes much of his time to maintaining the grounds and facilities at the pony club and has done so for many years. Incidentally, Doug would also tell you that his wife and daughter provide great assistance not only to him but to the club and the general community. Doug Dohle is a most deserving winner of this award and is truly representative of the community spirit that he has encouraged through the massive amount of time and energy he has devoted to his local community. As with most people who are warded in such a way for their outstanding service, Doug would never have expected, let alone thought he was deserving of, such an award. But Doug is now the Pine Rivers Citizen of the Year and he is a most worthy recipient. He truly deserves this recognition and I congratulate him on his dedication to not only the Pine Rivers Pony Club but to the district in general. Like all award winners on Australia Day, Doug has a loving family who have always encouraged him and given him the opportunity to fulfil his desire of giving to others.

Music is a vitally important component of many children's development, and Mr Timo Jarvela is the inspiration who has ensured thousands of schoolchildren's participation in music programs in Dickson, which is why he was awarded the cultural award on Australia Day. As an instrumental music teacher, Timo has continued to make the orchestras of Pine Rivers some of the best in the country. The children all love Timo as much as Timo loves teaching music. I congratulate Timo on his superb contribution to the musical community and wish him all the best for a great year ahead.

As everybody in this parliament would be only too aware, sport plays a major role in our communities and is enjoyed by almost every Australian at some time in their life. This year, the Pine Rivers senior sportsperson of the year award was given to someone very special, someone who has overcome great obstacles to achieve in her chosen field: Mrs Mary Albrow. Mary, who is a transplant recipient, nearly drowned as a child but learnt to swim last year and in fact was placed in the swim events at the Transplant Games. I believe that Mary is a great example of what can be achieved at any age and that, if you really want to do something, anything can be achieved. Every person, regardless of their age, can take inspiration from Mary's achievements and dedication. I congratulate Mary and thank her for inspiring our community.

Swimming is quite obviously a very popular sport in Australia, as the Pine Rivers junior sportsperson of the year is also a swimmer. Jessicah Schipper, a 16-year-old from Murrumba Downs, in the northern part of the Dickson electorate, recently became only the third Australian woman to swim a 100-metre butterfly race in under one minute—an absolutely marvellous achievement. Jessicah has a huge future in front of her in the swimming pool, and I look forward to seeing her win gold for Australia at the Commonwealth and Olympic Games in the coming years.

While it all looks too easy for some sports men and women, there are countless people who are not usually recognised for their contribution because they have not played in the winning team or, for that matter, in any team. They are the people who organise the fixtures, promote the sign-on days and run the clubs. In 2003, a very deserving Bruce Boland was named the Pine Rivers sports administrator of the year, for his contribution as vice-president at the Albany Creek Cricket Club. Bruce puts enormous amounts of time into the club through his administration, and is a great asset to the game. Without people like Bruce, our children could not be given the opportunity to participate in and play the sports they do. Every sporting and voluntary club in Australia needs a Bruce Boland to keep it moving. Some clubs will have someone like Bruce; some will not. I congratulate Bruce on this award and look forward to seeing many more great results from the Albany Creek Cricket Club next summer.

This year the community event of the year award was given to a fabulous event in my community—the Albany Fair. I congratulate every person who helped with the organisation of that event for their time and effort, and I look forward to another great fair this coming year. I congratulate again all of the Australia Day award recipients. I thank them for contributing to and inspiring our community in Dickson, and I wish them all the very best for this year.

talk.start.para: —Everybody celebrates different things on Australia Day. Many people celebrate their new life in our great nation. Perhaps in uncertain times many others celebrate the security and safety we share, as a fair and democratic nation. While plenty choose to make the most of the last long weekend before the new year truly kicks in, others choose not to celebrate but to reflect on our past treatment of our land's traditional owners. On Australia Day, I choose to honour the great people in the electorate of Lilley. For the past eight years, I have shared our national day with the unsung heroes of our local community. This year, the Lilley Australia Day Awards honoured 46 fantastic Australians—quiet achievers chosen by the Lilley Australia Day Awards Committee. While many of these people are strangers to each other, they have one overwhelming quality in common: they volunteer their time selflessly to the Lilley community. That is the essential criterion of the Lilley Australia Day Awards. These people donate their time and care to the community and ask for nothing in return. They see others needing help and they help them. They ask nothing more for themselves than the sheer pleasure of helping others.

speech.para: Our nation's volunteers perform an incredible amount of work in the community. At this moment there are volunteers around the country in the Rural Fire Service ready to fight bushfires. Over the past few months state emergency services in practically every state have had to deal with the aftermath of the incredible devastation caused by fire. We saw it here only a few weeks ago. In my electorate there are volunteers like Charlie's Angels at the Prince Charles Hospital in Chermside, who work tirelessly to cheer up the sick and free up valuable staff. Many volunteers in Lilley give their time to our schools. They work in the tuckshops, raise money with raffles and fetes, and help out with junior sports teams and parents' associations so our children can get the best education we can provide them with.

Countless numbers of Lilley's senior citizens depend on the Meals on Wheels service from centres like Sandgate, Burnie Brae, Banyo, Chermside, Geebung and Crosby Park. Many in the veterans' community likewise depend on the assistance that volunteers provide through RSL subbranches and organisations like the War Widows Guild which advocate on their behalf. They depend on people like Jack Mundy from the Geebung-Zillmere-Aspley-Bald Hills subbranch, who clocked up 50 years of service with the RSL this year. In Lilley we also have people like Jennifer Singfield, who has been involved in the Sea Scouts and the Keep Sandgate Beautiful project and has worked to clean up Cabbage Tree Creek; Sandra Clark, who has volunteered for Meals on Wheels for 20 years; Reg Cosgrove, who has given tireless assistance to young people; and Marlene Hatton, who has spent 25 years raising funds to assist World Vision.

In my view, this is the type of person local communities want recognised on Australia Day. Our nation's volunteers are the most important contributors to our nation's wellbeing. They are the glue that holds the fabric of any community together. They are the glue that makes this country strong. They deserve recognition for their unpaid gift to our community. Therefore, it is disappointing to see so few of those who make the Australia Day honours list nominated for unpaid work. Indeed, when I searched the official 2003 Australia Day list on the Internet, I found only eight of 812 recipients cited with the words `volunteer' or `voluntary'.

In no way do I want to reflect on any of this year's awardees. I am sure they are all very deserving. However, we should remember that the highest awards in the Australian honours system are regularly filled by those who are awarded for work they have been paid to do—judges, senior officials, doctors, lawyers, academics, sports people and politicians. They have all been paid to do this work. So legitimate questions ought to be asked, such as: how many of these people give something back to the community for nothing during their lives or after they conclude their well paid careers? Not too many. There should be more who do. I wonder about this.

This year's Lilley Australia Day Awards recognised my predecessor in this House, Mrs Elizabeth Grace. She has been recognised because, in the years since she left parliament, she has been serving the community in a senior citizens' centre—the Golden Years at Nundah. I think she deserves the highest respect for this. The point is that I wish the high-flyers in our community and others who have been well paid and honoured would do the same. They ought to put something back into the community after they have been in well paid jobs and honoured for that.

No doubt this year our Australian of the Year, Dr Fiona Stanley, has done that. Not only has she been paid over the years; she has also been a volunteer. We need more people in this category honoured in our national awards. We need more people like these quiet achievers, who are not being paid for their work, that we have honoured in the Lilley Australia Day Awards. The system needs a dramatic shake-up, and there needs to be a much bigger emphasis on voluntary efforts. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On this occasion I could not agree more with what the member for Lilley has just said in this chamber. I thank him for his acknowledgment of former member Mrs Elizabeth Grace. Today I would like to talk about the automobile industry. It is the largest manufacturing industry in South Australia, directly employing more than 13,000 people in my home state. Of the more than 350,000 cars made in Australia each year, around half are manufactured in South Australia at the Holden and Mitsubishi plants. In addition, more than 40 component manufacturers supply the car industry with tyres, steel and alloy wheels, engine components, rear view mirrors, seats, suspension modules, mouldings and exhaust systems.

speech.para: On Saturday, 25 January, I had the honour of representing the federal government at the announcement by Holden of its intention to employ a further 1,000 people at its Elizabeth plant. The announcement by Holden of a third shift confirms how important the Elizabeth plant is to Holden and to the Australian industry. The plant is the heart of the Holden enterprise. It employs more than 4,000 local people in assembling 28 locally produced models. Of great importance to the South Australian economy, it is of particular importance to the economic and social wellbeing of the people of the northern and north-eastern suburbs of Adelaide, many of whom live within my electorate of Makin. The massive expansion program will enable Holden to pursue new export opportunities and increase the number of models produced at the Elizabeth plant from 28 to 35. Last year, Holden confirmed its position as the leading car manufacturer in Australia—it achieved an all-time record with sales of more than 178,000 vehicles, including more than 88,000 Commodores. That represents almost 22 per cent of the new vehicle market.

Holden's success in the domestic market is being matched by its growing presence in international markets. In 2001, Holden sold almost $1.2 billion worth of exports. One of the most exciting breakthroughs last year was the announcement that Holden would begin selling its award winning Monaro to the United States, re-badged as the legendary Pontiac GTO. American car industry leaders saw in Holden a company that could provide new, exciting models in an otherwise stale US market.

The creation of 1,000 new jobs at Holden's Elizabeth plant will be a tremendous injection into the local economy. The Howard government has been, and will continue to be, a strong partner in the success of Holden and our other Australian car manufacturers. In 1997, the Howard government announced a tariff freeze and a five-year $2.8 billion program of assistance to support the car industry to become more competitive. Only a few weeks before the Holden announcement, the Howard government announced the next stage in its long-term plans for the car industry. This second stage boosts industry assistance to an unprecedented $4.2 billion and will see the industry through to 2015. When that program ends, the Howard government will have given the industry 15 years of certainty and $7 billion in support. No-one could credibly argue that this government is not doing enough to support the automobile industry in Australia.

The results of this policy speak for themselves. Australian cars are being produced in greater numbers than eight years ago. Our exports of automotive products have tripled since 1996 and are worth almost $5 billion—and the industry is predicting it will achieve $10 billion in exports by 2010. Last year was a record year for the industry as a whole, with almost 825,000 new vehicles sold. The quality of Australian cars has vastly improved and, perhaps for the first time, is genuinely world class. The success of our exports in more than 30 countries worldwide confirms that our industry is a world beater. I know that the workers at the Elizabeth plant, many of whom are my constituents, take pride in their work. They should know that they are contributing to the success of one of the most important industries in Australia. As their federal representative, I was pleased to have had the opportunity to welcome Holden's latest expansion at its Elizabeth plant. The confidence expressed by Holden in the future of the industry in South Australia is a great boost to the local community and a sure sign that the policies of the Howard government are bringing great benefits to the people of Makin.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak today on an issue that has been causing me concern for some time—that is, the proposed Australia-US free trade agreement, or FTA. I would like to place on the record that I am not against free trade. The liberalisation of trade barriers over last two decades has greatly expanded the Australian economy and has, I believe, contributed to wealth generation in Australia. I do have concerns with a number of issues regarding this FTA. Firstly, I am concerned about the secretive approach to the progress of negotiations, creating suspicions in the community as to the trade-offs that are now being negotiated. Secondly, I am concerned about the effects that this agreement may have on a number of our industries, particularly those in the services sector. Thirdly, I am concerned that our strong trade relationships with our neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region could be unduly affected by an FTA between Australia and the US.

speech.para: I was disturbed to hear earlier last month that the government has been involved in secret—and I emphasise the word `secret'—discussions and has refused to open up public debate on this issue. I would have thought that this proposed FTA was of such economic importance to the country that the Australian public should have the ability to make worthwhile contributions to the debate. The US has had no such difficulties with opening the FTA negotiations to public debate in their country. The US Trade Representative, Robert Zoellick, has provided a briefing to the Congress and submissions have opened, with various interest groups raising their concerns about a number of issues.

Notably, the most vocal of these people were those involved in the agricultural sector. US farmers involved in the beef, sugar, dairy and grain industries have all demanded that Australian imports in those industries be subject to significant barriers to entry. It is no secret that our agricultural sector is the most efficient in the world, and American farmers fear that our lower cost and better quality products entering the US market may prove to be more competitive in the marketplace. The US dairy industry went as far as to say, `Opening the US market to Australian dairy farmers could endanger US security.'

The US agricultural sector has a very strong political influence and has been influential in the election of the Bush administration in 2000 and the success of the Republican Party in the recent Congressional elections. This sector has won significant concessions from the Bush administration and, with growing political support from farmers, I doubt that the administration would concede much to Australian farmers.

Reportedly, the US has made some demands of its own that would impact significantly on a number of our most important industries. Issues for the US include the winding back of the single desk for Australian wheat and Australia's strong quarantine laws, greater access to our broadcasting services, government services and the health and education sectors. Robert Zoellick has been placing significant pressure on the Canadians to abolish their single desk arrangements and has stated on the public record that the US wants the abolition of all monopoly powers held by state enterprises. The National Farmers Federation is rightly concerned about this threat.

The huge US companies that dominate the global pharmaceutical industry have also placed significant pressure on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, the PBS. Industry lobbyist Joe Damond told public hearings into the FTA that the PBS prohibited the freedom of pharmaceutical companies to charge higher prices for new products on the market and they were concerned about the subsidies of a number of popular products that, in their minds, should be more profitable. The PBS is an important part of the Australian public policy framework, and has been for half a century. It has made medicines affordable for people who would otherwise have to suffer just because they are poor. We cannot and must not allow this to be traded off.

The US also would like the Foreign Investment Review Board to be abolished. Our education sector is also on the agenda so that rich American kids can easily obtain a quality Australian education. The truth is that Australia will not obtain the same concessions from the US. How can we? The Australian economy is only one twenty-fifth of the size of the American economy. California has a larger economy that Australia has. Our negotiating power is limited, and we have to be careful about the motives of the companies that are strongly supporting this. These companies include General Motors, Citigroup, and Proctor and Gamble.

All of this is occurring at a time when we are suffering a fall in exports to our most important trading region, East Asia. In the last 12 months, merchandise exports to that region have fallen by 3.7 per cent, and this is at a time when there has been economic growth in the region of five per cent. The argument that this is due to the drought does not stack up, and the argument that it is due to an international recession does not either. The truth is that this government has decided to let fade away the diversification programs of the previous Labor government. Labor developed a program that would see Australia able to export with strength even in times of drought. The international markets could view Australia as more than an agricultural and commodity based economy. The reason our dollar has been so low is that we are again viewed as a farm and a quarry. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak today about the fires that have ravaged parts of my electorate of Farrer. The Snowy Mountains townships of Talbingo, Khancoban and especially the tiny town of Cabramurra, Australia's highest town, were under threat. Thousands of acres of pine plantations, including many trees that are 30 years old, could have gone up in smoke. The Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Authority sustained considerable damage to its communications systems and roads network, with some direct damage to power stations but thankfully nowhere near as much as there could have been.

speech.para: The Khancoban water catchment has been burnt out and the town of Tumbarumba was threatened. Tumbarumba is on emergency water supplies. Fires that might have negatively impacted upon the regional economy are now well and truly under control. But of course only a really brave soul would say that it is all over, because storms are forecast for later this week and we are still well and truly in the grip of the fire season. We now have to concentrate on the task of recovery and we have to thank members of the community for what they have done for the forests, the towns and for each other, whether it was in an official or unofficial capacity. There will be long-term effects that we cannot yet determine on our forestry and forest products industries which harvest from the area between Tumut, Tumbarumba and Canberra—not forgetting that the whole of the Victorian high country is burning.

Kosciusko National Park, an Australian icon, has been burnt beyond recognition. As much as three-quarters of the total park, part of which is in my electorate and part of which is in the electorate of Eden-Monaro, is gone. Flying over the forests on the way up to Canberra, the desolation is striking. The heat of the fires has obviously been extraordinarily intense in some parts, so much so that the trees are just ashen sticks. Even from 9,000 feet high you can see clearly the ground between them, black and wasted and such wide expanses of it. Never has our native bush seemed so fragile or so vulnerable and the point is that it is all lost; it is just not there any more. To say that it has been burnt could imply that it has been damaged but it will recover. It has not been damaged; it has been lost. It was quite apparent that there was nothing moving and nothing alive down there, nor would there be for a very long time.

People may be used to the rapid regeneration that we experienced after the Sydney bushfires, but it will not be the case here. This country is colder. The terrain is steep, rugged and inhospitable. The subsoil will wash away along with rocks and sticks and will damage our waterways. My immediate response, perhaps not quite logical, was that I felt that as custodians of our natural environment we have visited a terrible destruction on it and we have done very wrong, and I just felt very sorry.

The community as a whole has much to learn from these fires. We need a renewed appreciation of the power of the natural world in which we live and we need to recognise that the human race has no choice but to adapt our world and ourselves to strike a balance which serves the interests of both. I believe the balance has tipped too far towards not interfering with nature and towards allowing extremes of untouched wilderness to prevail. We know that wilderness is precious, but we should know that it is unnatural for it not to burn. Areas of the park exploded from treetop to treetop, within areas normally too wet to burn.

This was an exceptional fire: fuel reduction and grazing on high country leases would not have prevented it, but they would have improved our chances of fighting it. A slow, cool burn allows animals to escape, usually high in the trees as it moves through the undergrowth. Perhaps the procedure the park management needs to undergo to conduct hazard reduction burns needs to be looked at. I understand the approval process takes weeks and I have no doubt this reflects community hesitation over regular widespread controlled burning but in a temperate rainforest like Kosciusko, the window of opportunity is small and the local management needs to be able to act decisively and swiftly.

The equivalent of many years of forestry logging allocation in New South Wales has been destroyed by these bushfires. In New South Wales there are 516 parks and reserves. Two hundred and thirty-seven of these need fire management plans, but to date only 10 of these plans have been made public. New South Wales does not have a management plan for the Brindabella National Park and, on the New South Wales parks and wildlife web site, under the fire management section for Kosciusko, it states that at present the service has insufficient resources to undertake the full range of fire management responsibilities. Three hundred and thirty thousand hectares of the park have been burnt. But I understand the plan is under review and that fire management will be considered a priority. I know that those who conduct such reviews are people who have the best interests of the park at heart. If there are lessons to be learned, I am sure they will be. This is not a criticism of the people who work within the organisation. We all labour under excessive rules and regulations. I encourage the New South Wales government to allocate more resources in this vital area and to listen to the wise views of local people.

talk.start.para: —On 13 February 2001 I placed a simple question on the House of Representatives Notice Paper, directed to the Treasurer. That question, No. 43, states:

quote.para: What percentage of barristers and solicitors pay the top marginal rate of income tax?

speech.para: Despite a number of speeches and requests to the Speaker over the last 12 months, Treasurer Costello refuses to answer this question. I am aware that in his possession at the moment is a report, following the laudable revelations by Paul Barry in the Sydney Morning Herald about the abuse visited on the taxation system by barristers, and that the Assistant Treasurer and the Attorney-General know that 80 per cent of barristers do not pay the top marginal rate of tax. Something has got to be done about it.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of allegations that the contractor responsible for the drainage works at the immigration detention facility at Baxter removed a number of trees on and around the site.
(2) Has this site been subject to re-afforestation efforts, with assistance from Greening Australia, in recent years.
(3) Was the contractor required to rethink its approach to the drainage.
(4) What was the additional cost caused by the contractor having to re-do the drainage arrangements.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The drainage contractor removed a handful of small trees and shrubs from the area where the accommodation compounds were to be located and a number of salt-bush shrubs for the construction of a sewage evaporation pond. The location of services and buildings was planned to minimise the removal of trees and shrubs. A small number of trees and several shrubs were required to be removed as part of installation of the physical security arrangements. This work was undertaken by a separate contractor.
Under an agreement with the Department of Defence initiated by my department, each tree and shrub removed is to be replaced at a ratio of 2 to 1.
(2) The Department of Defence has advised that there have been no re-afforestation efforts at the site in recent years.
(3) The contractor was not required to rethink or redo the drainage.
(4) Not applicable - see (3) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 2002:

question.para: Further to the 2002 Budget reference to the as-yet-unconstructed Brisbane facility whose costings are marked “Not for publication”, has the Government abandoned its plans to build this facility; if not, why are its costs marked “Not for publication”.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Government has not abandoned its plans to build a facility in South East Queensland with consultations continuing.

Funding for the acquisition of land for a facility in South East Queensland was included in the 2002 Budget on a not for publication basis to avoid any potential prejudice to acquisition of a site within the budget provision.
